docs.title: Darling - macOS Translation Layer for Linux
Darling - macOS Translation Layer for Linux
docs.text:
Darling is a translation layer that allows you to run macOS software on Linux. It functions similarly to Wine (which runs Windows apps on Linux), but is focused specifically on Darwin and macOS binaries. Darling emulates a complete Darwin environment and provides a compatible layer to execute macOS executables.

Site Access

Use Google/Next/CloudFlare DNS to reach this.

https://www.darlinghq.org/

docs.title: Features of Darling for Linux
docs.text:
• Run unmodified macOS binaries on Linux
  • Support for GUI applications using Apple's frameworks
  • Integration with Linux filesystem and environment
  • Brew compatibility for installing macOS CLI utilities within Darling

docs.title: Ubuntu / Debian-based Systems
docs.text:
sudo apt install cmake clang bison flex libfuse-dev libudev-dev pkg-config python3 python3-pip git

# Clone the Darling repo
git clone --recursive https://github.com/darlinghq/darling.git
cd darling

# Build and install
mkdir build && cd build
cmake ..
make
sudo make install

Or, to run from the source tree (recommended):

make run

Note: Darling requires a kernel with FUSE support enabled. Make sure FUSE is properly installed and the fusermount command is available.

docs.title: Arch Linux (and derivatives)
docs.text:
Darling is available via the AUR:

yay -S darling-git

Start the shell:

darling shell

You may need yay or another AUR helper. Ensure fuse2 and fakeroot are installed.

docs.title: WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux)
docs.text:
Darling does not currently run under WSL1 or WSL2 due to missing kernel module support (notably FUSE). For experimental purposes:

  • Use a full Linux VM or bare-metal Linux install.
  • Monitor Darling issues for WSL updates.

⚠️ FUSE and Darling kernel modules are not supported in WSL at this time.

docs.title: Using Darling for Linux
docs.text:
Start the Darling shell:

darling shell

This opens a shell inside the Darling macOS-like environment. You can then run macOS commands and install applications as if on a macOS system.

docs.title: Installing macOS Applications in Darling for Linux
docs.text: You can copy .app bundles or macOS CLI binaries into Darling's environment and run them:

docs.title: GUI Application Example
docs.text:
# From the Darling shell
cp -r /Volumes/Installer/AppName.app /Applications/
open /Applications/AppName.app

docs.title: CLI Binary Example
docs.text:
# From the host Linux terminal
darling shell
curl -O https://example.com/mac-cli-tool
chmod +x mac-cli-tool
./mac-cli-tool

GUI support is still limited; CLI apps are more likely to work reliably.

docs.title: Using Homebrew inside Darling for Linux
docs.text: Darling supports running macOS Homebrew within its environment:

docs.title: Steps Getting Homebrew working:
docs.text:
darling shell
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

After installation, you can use brew to install macOS software inside Darling:

brew install coreutils
ls /usr/local/bin

Remember, only Darwin/macOS formulae will work. Linux-specific formulae will not function.

docs.title: Limitations of Darling for Linux
docs.text:
• No support for modern macOS GUI apps requiring Metal or other advanced graphics frameworks
  • Limited support for full applications due to security frameworks, system calls, etc.
  • Designed primarily for x86_64 Linux (ARM64 support is experimental)

FROM ubuntu:18.04

 && apt-get install -y sudo

USER docker

Alternate:

...
RUN apt-get update \
 && apt-get install -y sudo

RUN \
    groupadd -g 999 foo && useradd -u 999 -g foo -G sudo -m -s /bin/bash foo && \
    sed -i /etc/sudoers -re 's/^%sudo.*/%sudo ALL=(ALL:ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL/g' && \
    sed -i /etc/sudoers -re 's/^root.*/root ALL=(ALL:ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL/g' && \
    sed -i /etc/sudoers -re 's/^#includedir.*/## **Removed the include directive** ##"/g' && \
    echo "foo ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL" >> /etc/sudoers && \
    echo "Customized the sudoers file for passwordless access to the foo user!" && \
    echo "foo user:";  su - foo -c id

# Now, in the container, install rsync

exit

Features of the rsync Image for Copying:

  • It is incredibly fast
  • It’s more reliable to copy large files or directories and it allows stop and resume if needed.

      rsync:alpine \

-p 1883:1883 - connect local port 1883 to exposed internal MQTT port 1883
-p 5683:5683 - connect local port 5683 to exposed internal COAP port 5683
-v ~/.mytb-data:/data - mounts the host’s dir ~/.mytb-data to ThingsBoard DataBase data directory
-v ~/.mytb-logs:/var/log/thingsboard - mounts the host’s dir ~/.mytb-logs to ThingsBoard logs directory
--name mytb - friendly local name of this machine
--restart always - automatically start ThingsBoard in case of system reboot and restart in case of failure.
thingsboard/tb-postgres - docker image, can be also thingsboard/tb-cassandra or thingsboard/tb

After executing this command you can open http://{your-host-ip}:9090 in you browser (for ex. http://localhost:9090). You should see ThingsBoard login page. Use the following default credentials:

Systen Administrator: sysadmin@thingsboard.org / sysadmin
Tenant Administrator: tenant@thingsboard.org / tenant
Customer User: customer@thingsboard.org / customer

You can always change passwords for each account in account profile page.

docs.title: fail2ban - Security Service
docs.text:
Homepage http://www.fail2ban.org/

Reference Video:

  • Fail2ban Tutorial | How to Secure Your Server

    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kgdoVeyoO2E

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ukHcTCdOKrc

Reference Article:

  • https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-fail2ban-works-to-protect-services-on-a-linux-server

    PDF

Sources: https://github.com/fail2ban/fail2ban

Fail2ban, written in Python, is a scanner that examines the log files produced by the Linux System, and checks them for suspicious activity. It catches things like multiple brute-force attempts to log in, and can inform any installed firewall to stop further login attempts from suspicious IP addresses.

If you’re exposing port 22 for SSH, it’s recommended to install fail2ban. If you’re simply using OpenVPN via PiVPN, then fail2ban isn’t required.

docs.title: Installation of fail2ban
docs.text: sudo apt install fail2ban

docs.title: Configuration of fail2ban for sshd and ufw
docs.text:
Fail2ban Tutorial | How to Secure Your Server

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kgdoVeyoO2E

Step 1 Copy the main configuration file fail2ban.conf to its local version for overrides. And similarly the jail.conf file needs to copied to local version.

sudo cp /etc/fail2ban/fail2ban.conf /etc/fail2ban/fail2ban.local
sudo cp /etc/fail2ban/jail.conf /etc/fail2ban/jail.local
Step 2 Edit the jail.local file for enabling the features. 
sudo nano /etc/fail2ban/jail.local

Here are the list of modifications needed:

  • ignoreip remove the comment on this line it should look like:

    ignoreip = 127.0.0.1/8 ::1

    You can also add your own IP address or local address if needed.

    For Example lets say we have local network address as 192.168.20.X

    We can add this here as:

    ignoreip = 127.0.0.1/8 ::1 192.168.20.0/24

  • bantime this can enforce more time for blocking the invalid users.

    By default this is 10 minutes indicated by bantime = 10m

    Increasing this will increase the time it takes to restore connection in case there was a failed attempt.

  • findtime and maxretry This determines the condition of failures after which the IP gets banned.

    This is by default findtime = 10m and maxretry = 5

    Meaning that if there are 5 failed attempts in 10 minutes the IP gets banned.

    This can be altered to suit specific cases.

  • backend this helps with logging features and controlling Fail2ban

    If you have systemd then we need to change it from the default auto to

    backend = systemd

  • sendmail for Mail alerts from Fail2Ban we need to install sendmail and modify destemail = root@localhost and sender = root@<fq-hostname>

    Note: This is apart from the standard logging.

  • Jails These are the specific configurations for the blocking on specific services.

  • [sshd] Jail the Very Important one

    Add enabled = true right under the [sshd] header to enable this.

    We would also add a backend for logging backend = systemd and the special log file path for easier access.

    You can also customize the port in case your SSHD configuration is using a custom port.

    It should look like this:

    [sshd]
enabled = true
backend = systemd
logpath = /var/log/fail2ban-sshd-auth.log
# To use more aggressive sshd modes set filter parameter "mode" in jail.local:
# normal (default), ddos, extra or aggressive (combines all).
# See "tests/files/logs/sshd" or "filter.d/sshd.conf" for usage example and details.
#mode   = normal
port    = ssh
#logpath = %(sshd_log)s
#backend = %(sshd_backend)s

  • Other Jails These need to be enabled based on what services are already running.

    Means that if we have apache or nginix running then we can enable their specific Jails else do not enable others.

    And to enable the same go to the [<service>] header and add enabled = true.

Make sure to save the file.

Step 3 Update the /etc/fail2ban/fail2ban.local file with new option

sudo nano /etc/fail2ban/fail2ban.local

  • In the [Definition] section:

    # set it to yes, on, true of 1 to force fail2ban to acknowledge IPv6 is present:
allowipv6 = no

Make sure to save the file.

docs.title: Enable fail2ban and restart it
docs.text:
# Start `fail2ban` now
sudo systemctl enable --now fail2ban

Restart it in case you have added the jail.local file:

sudo systemctl restart fail2ban

Finally restart the sshd a.k.a openSSH Server.

sudo systemctl restart sshd

Check the Fail2Ban using the fail2ban-client utility:

sudo fail2ban-client status

This should show the sshd Jail being active.

docs.title: Location for the log files for Fail2Ban
docs.text:
cat /var/log/fail2ban.log

Any additional logs can also be trailed in fail2ban name in the same location.

curl -F'file=@yourfile.png' -Fexpires=24 https://0x0.st

# Expired files won't be removed immediately but within the next minute.

https://transfer.sh/

Here are some significant features that transfer.sh offers:

  • Requires no GUI, uses the command line.

transfer(){ if [ $# -eq 0 ];then echo "No arguments specified.\nUsage:\n transfer <file|directory>\n ... | transfer <file_name>">&2;return 1;fi;if tty -s;then file="$1";file_name=$(basename "$file");if [ ! -e "$file" ];then echo "$file: No such file or directory">&2;return 1;fi;if [ -d "$file" ];then file_name="$file_name.zip" ,;(cd "$file"&&zip -r -q - .)|curl --progress-bar --upload-file "-" "https://transfer.sh/$file_name"|tee /dev/null,;else cat "$file"|curl --progress-bar --upload-file "-" "https://transfer.sh/$file_name"|tee /dev/null;fi;else file_name=$1;curl --progress-bar --upload-file "-" "https://transfer.sh/$file_name"|tee /dev/null;fi;}

docs.text:
Github: https://github.com/netblue30/firejail

Home Page: https://firejail.wordpress.com/

ArchLinux Wiki: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Firejail

My main motivation behind studying firejail was to block the telemetry from VS Code and FreeFileSync like programs. The purpose of firejail being able to block Network access on applications.

This was a very complex way to achieve the goal while flatpak actually did this much simply.

docs.title: What is firejail ?
docs.text: firejail is a SUID sandbox program that reduces the risk of security breaches by restricting the running environment of untrusted applications using Linux namespaces and seccomp-bpf. It includes security profiles for over 1000 common Linux applications such as Firefox, Chromium, Transmission, VLC etc.

docs.title: Magic of firejail
docs.text:
You can do lots of useful things like:

  • Disable access to Internet for selected programs.
  • Control which directories are accessible to programs.
  • Use different configuration of the same program for different use-cases.
  • Keep telemetry sending programs in check.
  • All this in the classical way of the Linux command line!

docs.title: Install Steps for ArchLinux
docs.text:
Video for this : https://odysee.com/@netblue30:9/archlinux:d2e

The steps are as follows:

  1. Install Firejail software using pacman package manager: $ sudo pacman -S firejail
  2. Configure the sandbox - this step integrates the sandbox with your desktop manager. $ sudo firecfg
  3. Enable AppArmor. Starting withversion 0.9.62, AppArmor is enabled automatically during configuration (step 2 above). $ sudo apparmor_parser -r /etc/apparmor.d/firejail-default

Another nice piece that comes with firejail is FireTools. They make it easier to configure apps with special security Settings.

Here is a video showing the FireTools : https://odysee.com/@netblue30:9/firetools:6

docs.title: AppImage Special
docs.text:
Applying firejail for AppImage files.

AppImage is a Linux distribution agnostic format used by many software developers to package their programs. This shows you how to handle appimages in firejail security sandbox.

For more information, check https://firejail.wordpress.com/documentation-2/appimage-support/

We would create a shortcut for opening the specific AppImage from desktop.

[Desktop Entry]
Name=kdenlive
Exec=/usr/bin/firejail --net=none --appimage /opt/kdenlive-20.12.2-x86_64.appimage
Icon=/home/netblue/config/kdenlive.svg
Terminal=false
Type=Application

No Internet for kdenlive now !!

docs.title: Changing Hostname
docs.text:
This is kind of an important task on the Linux sphere.

We need to make sure that we are able to change the Hostname and not break our network configurations.

This becomes specially important for the non-systemd based systems. Typically there is no central utility in non-systemd/init.rc/initrc based system.

Here are the ways to deal with this.

docs.title: Reference
docs.text:
https://wiki.debian.org/Hostname?action=show&redirect=HowTo%2FChangeHostname

Here is the PDF of the article.

This article goes in detail of Renaming a computer and much more.

docs.title: Changing Computer name or Hostname on a non-systemd or init.rc based Linux
docs.text:
1. Update the Hostname in /etc/hostname

    sudo nano /etc/hostname

  2. Update the /etc/hosts

    sudo nano /etc/hosts

    Make sure it has the same name as the /etc/hostname file.

  3. Reload the configuration:

    sudo invoke-rc.d hostname.sh start
    This would invoke the update in the Hostname. 
    sudo invoke-rc.d networking force-reload

    This would allow the reload the local networking.

    sudo invoke-rc.d network-manager force-reload

    This would actually update the changes.

  4. Alternatively, you can just Restart the PC to solve this.

Note: With Linux using doas just replace the sudo and things should work the same.

docs.title: Changing Computer name or Hostname on systemd based Linux
docs.text: sudo hostnamectl set-hostname <your-machine-name>

docs.title: Application specific Reloads needed for Hostname changes
docs.text:
• Avahi

    sudo invoke-rc.d avahi-daemon force-reload

  • OpenSSH server

    sudo invoke-rc.d sshd force-reload

  • Possibly the last script in the reference is of great help:

#!/bin/bash
#
usage() {
   echo "usage : $0 <new hostname>"
   exit 1
}

[ "$1" ] || usage

old=$(hostname)
new=$1

for file in \
   /etc/exim4/update-exim4.conf.conf \
   /etc/printcap \
   /etc/hostname \
   /etc/hosts \
   /etc/ssh/ssh_host_rsa_key.pub \
   /etc/ssh/ssh_host_dsa_key.pub \
   /etc/motd \
   /etc/ssmtp/ssmtp.conf
do
   [ -f $file ] && sed -i.old -e "s:$old:$new:g" $file
done

docs.title: Caddy systemd Service and Manual Install
docs.text: Docs: https://caddyserver.com/docs/running

docs.title: 1. Download the correct version of Caddy as instructed above
docs.text:
https://caddyserver.com/download

https://caddyserver.com/download?package=github.com%2Fcaddy-dns%2Fduckdns

docs.title: 2. Copy Caddy as the Executable
docs.text:
sudo mv caddy /usr/bin/

Check if its installed correctly by:

caddy version

docs.title: 3. Setup User and Groups for Caddy to run
docs.text:
Create a group named caddy:

sudo groupadd --system caddy

Create a user named caddy with a writeable home directory:

sudo useradd --system \
    --gid caddy \
    --create-home \
    --home-dir /var/lib/caddy \
    --shell /usr/sbin/nologin \
    --comment "Caddy web server" \
    caddy

docs.title: 4. Download the systemd service Unit file
docs.text:
caddy.service File https://github.com/caddyserver/dist/blob/master/init/caddy.service

You can download this

wget -c https://github.com/caddyserver/dist/raw/refs/heads/master/init/caddy.service

Copy this file to the correct location:

sudo mv caddy.service /etc/systemd/system/caddy.service

Next create the Caddyfile.

The default one is available here

https://github.com/caddyserver/dist/blob/master/config/Caddyfile

wget -c https://github.com/caddyserver/dist/raw/refs/heads/master/config/Caddyfile && \
    sudo mv Caddyfile /etc/caddy/Caddyfile

You can edit this if needed:

sudo nano /etc/caddy/Caddyfile

Start the Caddy Service:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable --now caddy

Finally check the Status:

systemctl status caddy

To See the Caddy Service logs:

journalctl -u caddy --no-pager | less +G

In case you wish to update Caddy with a modification in Caddyfile then:

sudo systemctl reload caddy

Storage Location for Caddy Files

The Caddy process will run as the caddy user, which has its $HOME set to /var/lib/caddy. This means that:

  • The default data storage location (for certificates and other state information) will be in /var/lib/caddy/.local/share/caddy.

  • The default config storage location (for the auto-saved JSON config, primarily useful for the caddy-api service) will be in /var/lib/caddy/.config/caddy.

  • You can find the root CA certificate at /var/lib/caddy/.local/share/caddy/pki/authorities/local/root.crt. This in case Caddy acts as the internal issuer.

docs.title: 5. Adding Caddy Environment Variables to systemd Service
docs.text:
You need to edit the service unit:

sudo systemctl edit caddy

Add the content

[Service]
EnvironmentFile=/etc/caddy/.env

This specifies the new Environment File /etc/caddy/.env.

Now edit this file to add your environment configuration:

sudo nano /etc/caddy/.env

For our DuckDNS addon github.com/caddy-dns/duckdns :

DUCKDNS_API_TOKEN=YOUR_DUCKDNS_API_TOKEN

Finally restart the Service:

sudo systemctl restart caddy

docs.title: 6. Using the DuckDNS Challenge for ACME Certificate in Caddy
docs.text:
First get the Configuration token for DuckDNS.

Make sure its available in the Environ variable DUCKDNS_API_TOKEN by adding it to the /etc/caddy/.env as explained in the previous step.

Finally Edit your Main Caddyfile and add the following:

{
    # (Optional) Email for Let's Encrypt registration and urgent notices
    email youremail@example.com
}

# Set your DuckDNS API token in the environment:
#   export DUCKDNS_API_TOKEN="your-duckdns-token"
# Or you can put it directly below in place of {env.DUCKDNS_API_TOKEN}.
# Or use the '/etc/caddy/.env' for automatic injection (secure way).
<yoursite>.duckdns.org {
    # Use DNS-01 challenge via DuckDNS
    tls {
        dns duckdns {env.DUCKDNS_API_TOKEN}
    }

    # Reverse-proxy all requests to your local service
    reverse_proxy <your-server>:<server-port>
}

Finally restart the Caddy service to run this.

DuckDNS modules

You need to have the respective DuckDNS module enabled for this to work.

github.com/caddy-dns/duckdns

For this make sure to follow the Download instructions correctly.

docs.title: 7. Adding Multiple Site Configs to our default Caddyfile
docs.text:
First we create the Required directories:

sudo mkdir /etc/caddy/{sites-available,sites-enabled}

Next, we edit our Caddyfile:

sudo nano /etc/caddy/Caddyfile

At the end add:

import sites-enabled/*

Finally we like the items in our sites-available folder into the sites-enabled folder.

echo "example.net { reverse_proxy localhost:8080 }" | sudo tee /etc/caddy/sites-available/test-site

This would create a dummy entry for a local server running at port 8080.

Next we link this to the Configuration:

sudo ln -s /etc/caddy/sites-available/test-site \
    /etc/caddy/sites-enabled/test-site

This would create the link /etc/caddy/sites-enabled/test-site.

Now just reload the Caddy service and this would be part of the config.

docs.title: Important Commands and Snippets for LVM
Extend the logical volume under LVM
docs.text:
lvextend --resizefs -l +100%FREE /dev/mapper/vg_ubuntu-lv_root

This would resize the Logical Volume lv_root under the Volume group vg_ubuntu to take up the full space +100%FREE available.

Another way only give 10GiB to the lv_root:

lvextend -L +10G /dev/mapper/vg_ubuntu-lv_root
# Expand the Filesystem
resize2fs /dev/mapper/vg_ubuntu-lv_root

Using the --resizefs on can do the above in a single command.

docs.title: Convert a disk to an LVM physical volume
docs.text:
pvcreate /dev/sdb

Make sure that the /dev/sdb actually is your disk or change it accordingly. The above would create a Physical Volume out of disk /dev/sdb.

vgextend vg_ubuntu /dev/sdb

This would add the the Physical Volume in /dev/sdb into the Volume group vg_ubuntu.

vgdisplay

This would display the structure of the LVM setup.

docs.title: Creating a brand-new LVM setup
docs.text:
Convert the new disk to be an LVM physical volume:

pvcreate /dev/sdc

Make sure that the /dev/sdc actually is your disk or change it accordingly.

Create the volume group :

vgcreate vg_extra /dev/sdc

Check the volume group :

vgdisplay

Create a logical volume (named lv_logs in this example):

lvcreate vg_extra -L 5G -n lv_logs

Format the logical volume :

mkfs.ext4 /dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_logs

Path Format for Volume Group and Logical Volume

/dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_logs

Here the Volume Group is vg_extra.

And, Logical Volume is lv_logs.

Create a directory to mount the new logical volume :

mkdir /mnt/extra/logs

Mount the logical volume:

mount /dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_logs /mnt/extra/logs

Find the block id of the new logical volume:

blkid /dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_logs

Back up your fstab file to be safe:

cp /etc/fstab /etc/fstab.bak

Edit the fstab file:

nano /etc/fstab

Add a line to the fstab to mount the volume, similar to this:

UUID=<BLOCK ID FOR LOGICAL VOLUME> /mnt/extra/logs ext4 defaults 0 2

Test the new mount, first making sure it’s not mounted:

umount /mnt/extra/logs

mount -a

docs.title: Creating and Managing Snapshots in LVM
docs.text:
Create a new snapshot:

lvcreate /dev/mapper/<SOURCE VOLUMEGROUP NAME> -L 1G -s -n snapshot_name

Replace <SOURCE VOLUMEGROUP NAME> and snapshot_name accordingly.

View used space of snapshots:

lvs

Mount a snapshot:

mount /dev/mapper/vg_extra-web_snapshot_20200421 /mnt/extra/snapshot

Restore a Snapshot:

# Umount the Logical Volume
umount /dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_web
# Restore the Snapshot
lvconvert --merge /dev/mapper/snapshot_name
# Refresh
lvchange -an /dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_web
lvchange -ay /dev/mapper/vg_extra-lv_web

docs.title: Reduce/Shrink the LVM Volume
docs.text:
https://www.rootusers.com/lvm-resize-how-to-decrease-an-lvm-partition/

  1. First step is to unmount the target volume.

    Originally the volume is assumed to be 15GiB in size.

    For shrinking a root volume :

    # Reboot into a Live Medium and issue the following
vgchange -an /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume> # Disable

    Since reducing a root volume is not possible when the OS is booted. We would need to boot into a live medium OS to perform this.

    For all other Volumes:

    umount /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume>

  2. Check the file system that was unmounted:

    e2fsck -fy /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume>

  3. Shrink down the actual Filesystem in the Logical Volume :

    resize2fs /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume> 10G

    Size of Free Space in Partition

    The state of the Logical Volume begin shrunk should be such that' data content inside filesystem should be less than the desired size. In the above case it should be less than 10GiB.

  4. There can be two types of Reduction/Shrinkage commands:

    a. To Reduce to 10GiB: 

    lvreduce -L 10G /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume>
    This means the size specified is the absolute value of Size.

    b. To Reduce by 5GiB resulting in a 10GiB volume size: 

    lvreduce -L -5G /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume>
    This is taking away the free space in the volume by 5GiB.

  5. Fix the new Volume after resize:

    resize2fs /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume>

  6. Re-enable the LVM and mount the partition back:

    vgchange -ay /dev/mapper/<Your-Volume>
# In a CHroot environment try
mount -a

Proxmox VE (Virtual Environment) is an open-source server virtualization platform based on Debian Linux. It integrates KVM hypervisor, LXC containers, ZFS storage, and a powerful web-based GUI for managing virtual machines, containers, storage, and networking.

  • Website: https://www.proxmox.com/proxmox-ve
  • Git Repository: https://git.proxmox.com/

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Full virtualization with KVM
  • Lightweight container support with LXC
  • ZFS, LVM, Ceph, iSCSI, NFS, and CIFS storage support
  • Web GUI, CLI, and REST API interfaces
  • Live migration of VMs and containers
  • High availability clustering
  • Backup & restore with built-in scheduler
  • Role-based user and permission management

docs.title: Configuring Linux system to let disk spin down
Configuring Linux system to let disk spin down
Reasons
docs.text:
For always-on systems like NAS, which still should sleep most of the time, when not used.

Dedicated NAS, etc. systems usually have this covered, so particular focus of this note is for generic OSes like Debian.

Usual suspects:

  • Logging
    • System logging daemon, like rsyslog.
    • Adhoc logging of particular daemons, e.g. Samba.
  • Periodically running processes
    • cron
    • atd
  • systemd - really fits into 2 previous categories, but due to particular notoriety, NIH and proprietary design requires particular scrutiny.
    • systemd-timesyncd - proprietary NIH for ntpdate
    • systemd timers - proprietary NIH for cron
  • Swap
  • Buff/cache configuration

docs.title: Logging
docs.text: All logging should happen to tmpfs, with rotation to persistent storage.

docs.title: Periodically running processes
docs.text:
Running generic processes (executables) more often than once a day should be avoided. E.g., cron.hourly should be disabled.

atd, unless actually used, can be disabled too.

docs.title: Looking into systemd
docs.text: Contains a lot of proprietary, NIH services and daemons, not implemented with efficiency and configurability in mind. Newer version gradually offer more configurability, but the version you may run may not offer it. Overall, it's better to disable as many as possible proprietary systemd services and use classic Unix tools instead.

docs.title: systemd-timesycd - Time synchronization services
docs.text:
Runs often and writes to a disk on each time sync. Newer versions allow to configure polling interval, but older don't. Better to disable and use ntpdate if needed.

systemctl disable systemd-timesyncd

docs.title: systemd "timers"
docs.text:
Proprietary duplication of cron functionality. For each timer run, a file in /var/lib/systemd/timers/ is touched, so unless that's on tmpfs, triggering timer will always trigger disk spin up due to this writing (same issue as with systemd-timesyncd).

To list active timers:

systemctl list-timers

Then review and disable with:

systemctl disable apt-daily.timer
systemctl stop apt-daily.timer

Functionality if needed can be moved to cron.

docs.title: syncthing Enabled on ufw Firewall
docs.text:
A common issue faced is how to enable syncthing to work when its used directly as a binary package.

We look at the easy route.

docs.title: Get latest version of syncthing
docs.text:
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/releases/latest

You can download the latest release of syncthing directly from the repository.

docs.title: Locating the syncthing configuration for the ufw Firewall
docs.text:
Typically this is located inside the archive available for syncthing in case its installed that way.

We are looking for the syncthing-linux-amd64-vx.y.z.tar.gz file.

After un-archiving this file you will have a etc directory. Inside that we have <your location>/syncthing-linux-amd64-vx.y.z/etc/firewall-ufw Folder.

This contains the file we need syncthing.

So the resulting path will be:

<your location>/syncthing-linux-amd64-vx.y.z/etc/firewall-ufw/syncthing

This file plays the crucial role.

docs.title: Loading the syncthing profile into ufw
docs.text:
The profiles for ufw are stored at :

/etc/ufw/applications.d/

We need to copy our syncthing file to this location.

In case you install from repository or as a package this is done automatically for you.

Since, we are using the archive way we need to do this manually.

First change directory to the location where you have extracted the archive:

cd <your location>/syncthing-linux-amd64-vx.y.z

Copy the profile file to the ufw directory:

sudo cp etc/firewall-ufw/syncthing /etc/ufw/applications.d/

Update the ufw for this new profile:

sudo ufw app update syncthing

Finally Allow the syncthing to pass through ufw:

sudo ufw allow syncthing

This would allow syncthing traffic through the ufw firewall.

docs.title: systemd-boot alternate Bootloader
docs.text:
Default Boot packaged with systemd.

https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Systemd-boot

Here are steps for a typical ArchLinux install:

# Arch Install
# - ...Source Update & Update roots
# - ...ntp
# - ...Partition (No Swap)
# - ...Format
# Mount
mount /dev/vda2 /mnt
mkdir /mnt/boot
mount /dev/vda1 /mnt/boot
pacstrap /mnt base linux linux-firmware nano git amd-ucode
genfstb -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab
# Enter The install
arch-chroot /mnt
# Create the Swap File for 2GB
fallocate -l 2GB /swapfile
chmod 600 /swapfile
mkswap /swapfile
swapon /swapfile
# Add Swapfile to fstab
nano /etc/fstab
## .. Go to the end of the file and add
/swapfile  none  swap  defaults  0 0
## .. Save the Install
# - ...Configure Timezone
# - ...Generate Locale
# - ...Hostname and Hosts file
# - ...RootUser password `change`
# - ...Install Basic Tools
pacman -S efibootmgr networkmanager network-manager-applet wireless_tools \
  wpa_supplicant dialog os-prober mtools dosfstools base-devel linux-headers \
  xdg-user-dirs
# SystemD Boot
bootctl --path=/boot install
# Configuration of Boot - loader
nano /boot/loader/loader.conf
## .. Uncomment The timeout - Or the System directly boots-up
timeout 3
## .. Change the default line
default arch-*
## .. Save the File and exit
# Configuration of Boot - entries
nano /boot/loader/entries/arch.conf
## .. Title of the Machine
title    Arch Linux
linux    /vmlinuz-linux
initrd   /initramfs-linux.img
options  root=/dev/vda2 rw
## .. Save the File and Exit
# - ...Enable Services
systemctl enable NetworkManager
# - ...Add Local User
groupadd ab
useradd -m -g ab -G wheel -s /bin/bash ab
passwd ab
# - ...Add sudo Privileges
echo "ab ALL=(ALL) ALL" | tee /etc/sudoers.d/ab
# - ...Umount all Partitions
umount -a
reboot #or PowerOff
#####
# - ...Install SSH
sudo pacman -S openssh
sudo systemctl start sshd
# - ...add other parts
sudo pacman -S xf86-video-qxl # for VM
# - ...KDE Installation
sudo pacman -S xorg sddm plasma kde-applications-meta packagekit-qt5
sudo systemctl enable sddm

# Arch Install 2
timedatectl set-ntp true
# - ...Partition
# - ...Format the Partitions
# - ...Mount the Disks
# pacstrap
pacstrap /mnt base base-devel linux-lts linux-firmware vim git amd-ucode \
  man-db man-pages texinfo linux-lts-headers \
  inetutils netctl dhcpcd \
  sof-firmware s-nail nano
genfstab -U /mnt >> /etc/fstab
# Enter the Install
arch-chroot /mnt
# Stage 1

ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Asia/Kolkata /etc/localtime
hwclock --systohc

sed -i 's/#en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/g' /etc/locale.gen
sed -i 's/#en_IN/en_IN/g' /etc/locale.gen
echo "LANG=en_US.UTF-8" | tee /etc/locale.conf
echo "KEYMAP=us" | tee /etc/vconsole.conf
locale-gen

echo "vm1" | tee /etc/hostname
echo -e "127.0.0.1\tlocalhost
::1\t\tlocalhost" | tee -a /etc/hosts
echo -e "127.0.1.1\t$(cat /etc/hostname).localdomain $(cat /etc/hostname)" | \
  tee -a /etc/hosts

mkinitcpio -p linux-lts

passwd

bootctl --path=/boot install

sed -i '/default \c/default arch-*' /boot/loader/loader.conf

echo -e "title\tArch Linux
linux\t/vmlinux-linux
initrd\t/amd-ucode.img
initrd\t/initramfs-linux.img
options root=UUID=" | tee /boot/loader/entries/arch.conf

echo "$(lsblk -nld -o UUID /dev/vda3) rw" | tee -a /boot/loader/entries/arch.conf

bootctl update

docs.title: Autostart Script Using a .desktop file
docs.text:
Options by creating a .desktop file:

  1. Write a .desktop file at ~/.config/autostart/ like

    ~/.config/autostart/myscript.sh.desktop

    Note: This does not work for Window Managers without a session manager built in like xmonad, bspwm, dwm, i3wm, etc.

  2. Use the Startup Program option:

    For the Gnome based Linux like Ubuntu:

    System settings > Workspace > Startup and Shutdown > Autostart

    For XFCE based Linux:

    Session and Startup > Application Autostart

Here is a Sample .desktop file:

[Desktop Entry]
Name=My Script
Comment=Script for my Operation
Exec=/bin/bash -c '~/scripts/my-script.sh'
Icon=utilities-terminal
Terminal=true
Type=Application
Categories=Utility;System;

Note: This would also work for creating a .desktop for any script that you wish to execute with the double click facility.

ACTION=="add", SUBSYSTEM=="usb", ATTR{product}=="Razer Abyssus", ATTR{power/control}="on"

docs.title: Fix Multicast Packets problem
docs.text:
Typically over the network some devices such as switches and routers (L4 type) support Multicast Packets.

These case the following type of logs to appear in ufw:

Dec 19 00:50:57 myHostName kernel: [11777.374335] [UFW BLOCK] IN=wlan1 OUT= MAC=*:*:c1:*:2c:64:*:*:ef:e4:21:40:*:* SRC=192.168.1.1 DST=224.0.0.1 LEN=36 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=1 ID=0 DF PROTO=2

All these show up the 224.0.0.1, the multicast IP.

This can quickly fill up the system logs.

The problem is that your Linux PC is not configured to respond to these packets.

docs.title: Block Multicast Packets on ufw
docs.text:
The easy approach would be to block these completely.

sudo ufw deny to 224.0.0.1

Finally since these the silence of the logs has helped to look at other issues.

docs.title: USB Disk Health and Fake detection
USB Disk Health and Fake detection
docs.text:
This process can be used in case on SD Cards and other memory types also.

It helps to detect and root out fake capacity reported by some cheap USB drives and SD Cards.

References:

  • https://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/linux-check-the-physical-health-of-a-usb-stick-flash-drive/

docs.title: First Option: Using badblocks
docs.text:
Permanent Damage

This method though being destructive is very thorough.

In this method your disk will be made blank.

Means the Filesystem and Partitions are over written.

Be CAREFUL !!.

This method would not detect if your USB Disk or Pen-drive is fake,

It would only ensure that the physical health is good.

And since this is a Destructive test make sure to backup.

Here is how you go about.

docs.title: 1. First we need to make sure that the following is installed
docs.text:
# This includes the `badblocks`
sudo pacman -S e2fsprogs

Typically this is already available installed in Manjaro.

Links to e2fsprogs

for badblocks utility : https://archlinux.org/packages/core/x86_64/e2fsprogs/

Insight into badblocks command: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Badblocks

docs.title: 2. To check we insert the USB drive and identify its disk.
docs.text:
Warning

Do not mount the USB drive at this point !!!

# We are creating a 'error.log' file for any errors in the
# write process.
sudo badblocks -w -s -o error.log /dev/sdX

Here /dev/sdX is a placeholder replace it with the actual disk.

And to find out the disks mounted in your system use lsblk command.

This would take a while to complete.

docs.title: 3. Format Disk
docs.text: Finally after the test is over you can format the /dev/sdX to a FAT32 partition disk.

docs.title: Second Option: using f3 Program to detect fakes
docs.text:
This option is better in case you would like to only check the capacity.

Its to confirm if the USB Drive or Pen-drive is Fake or real.

Here is the project home-page:

https://github.com/AltraMayor/f3/

Also this method is non-destructive but needs a empty & formatted USB Disk/Pen-drive.

Here are the steps to do the full test:

docs.title: 1. We would fist need to install the dependency for f3
docs.text:
sudo yay -S f3
In Arch Linux its only available as a AUR package:

docs.title: Mounting a Container as read-only in veracrypt
docs.text:
veracrypt -t -k "" -m ro --pim=0 \
      --protect-hidden=no Container1 /mnt/veracrypt1
  • The -t option provides the CLI or the Text only interface.
  • The part -m ro is what makes the mount read-only.
  • And -k "" disables the key-files option.

Typically a encrypted volume as only one way to open it. However there may be many PIM slots used. In a default case using --pim=0 uses the first or only slot.

For this admin password as well as the encrypted volume password. For easier operation just add sudo in front.

In this case we are using a file Container1 is located in the current directory. It can also be a volume or disk like /dev/sda4 etc.

docs.title: Mounting a Container Normally to a Directory in veracrypt
docs.text:

     /Backup/Container1 /home/user/secure

Here the file /Backup/Container1 would get mounted to the existing directory in user home folder secure.

docs.text:
sudo veracrypt -t -k /Backup/secret.keyfile \
     --pim=0 --protect-hidden=no \
     /Backup/Container4 \
     ~/fixed

In the above command we are using the Key-file located at /Backup/secret.keyfile. This is typically in a Pen-Drive or another secure location. In this can no Password would be asked since we are providing the -k <Key-Fil> option.

docs.title: Fix Golang issues in Flatpak edition of VSCodium
docs.text:
Normally the Go extension would not be able to detect correct path for go binary even though its installed system wide.

Here is how you can go about installing Go and make it work with Flatpak edition of VSCodium.

docs.title: Installing Latest Golang under Linux
docs.text:
cd ~/Download

# Download the Go Install
wget -c https://go.dev/dl/go1.21.5.linux-amd64.tar.gz

# Do the Checksum
echo "e2bc0b3e4b64111ec117295c088bde5f00eeed1567999ff77bc859d7df70078e go1.21.5.linux-amd64.tar.gz" | sha256sum -c

# This will do the System wide install
sudo rm -rf /usr/local/go && sudo tar -C /usr/local -xzf go1.21.5.linux-amd64.tar.gz

# This is needed to make it work with VSCodium
tar -xzf go1.21.5.linux-amd64.tar.gz

# Add Golang into environment
echo "export GOROOT=/usr/local/go" | tee -a ~/.bashrc
echo "source \$GOROOT/go.env" | tee -a ~/.bashrc

# Create the GOHOME directories if they don't exist already
mkdir -p ~/go/{bin,pkg,src}

Also add the go binary and tools into your $PATH variable:

echo "export PATH=\$PATH:\$HOME/go/bin" | tee -a ~/.bashrc
echo "export PATH=\$PATH:/usr/local/go/bin" | tee -a ~/.bashrc
echo "export PATH=\$PATH:/usr/local/go/pkg/tool/linux_amd64" | tee -a ~/.bashrc

The last line would allow the Go binary to be available in ~/Downloads directory.

Warning! Reboot or Logout-Login to make sure that the changes are applied.

docs.title: Fix Permission for Downloads directory in flatseal for VSCodium
docs.text:
Next we need to add permission to access the Download directory using the flatseal app.

xdg-download:ro

This is the location where we also extract the go binaries in ~/Downloads/go/.... Its only needed for VS Codium and not in case of VS Code installed via flatpak.

docs.title: Update VSCodium Settings to recognize Golang
docs.text:
Finally we would need to edit the settings.json and add the following:

  // @ Go Plugin
  "go.inferGopath": true,
  "go.toolsManagement.autoUpdate": true,
  "go.alternateTools": {
    "go": "~/Downloads/go/bin/go"
  },
  // Obsolete
  //"go.languageServerExperimentalFeatures": {
  //    "diagnostics": false
  //},
  "go.testFlags": [
    "-v"
  ],
  // ## End - Go Plugin

This would allow to access go from the ~/Downloads/go path.

docs.title: Thicken the Text Caret in XFCE - Make Your Cursor Unmissable
Thicken the Text Caret in XFCE - Make Your Cursor Unmissable
docs.text: Accessability tweak for XFCE t make the Text cursor more visible.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This document describes how to increase the thickness of the text insertion cursor (caret) in XFCE using GTK3 settings. By applying a simple CSS override or modifying the GTK settings file, you can make the caret more visible in all GTK3 applications.

Note: This method works on any Linux distribution running XFCE with GTK3.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A running XFCE desktop environment.
  • Applications built with GTK3 (e.g., Mousepad, Thunar, gedit).
  • Basic familiarity with editing files under ~/.config/gtk-3.0/.

docs.title: Solution
docs.text: There are two primary methods to adjust the caret thickness:

docs.title: 1. GTK CSS Override
docs.text:
1. Create or open the file:
~/.config/gtk-3.0/gtk.css
2. Add the following CSS rule to control the caret aspect ratio: 
/* Increase caret thickness by adjusting the
   aspect ratio */
* {
    -GtkWidget-cursor-aspect-ratio: 0.1;
    /* Try 0.05, 0.1, or 0.2 for different
       thickness */
}
3. Save the file.

docs.title: 2. GTK Settings File (settings.ini)
docs.text:
1. Create or open the file:
~/.config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini
2. Ensure it contains the following: 
[Settings]
gtk-cursor-aspect-ratio=0.1
3. Save the file.

docs.title: Applying Changes
docs.text:
After updating either of the above files:

  1. Restart affected GTK3 applications (e.g., close and reopen Mousepad).
  2. Optional: Log out of your XFCE session and log back in to reload all GTK settings at once.

Note: A full system reboot is not required.

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
• Open a GTK3-based text editor (e.g., Mousepad).
  • Click into a text area and confirm that the caret appears thicker according to the value you set.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• If the caret does not change:

  • Verify the file paths and names (gtk.css vs. settings.ini).

  • Check for typos in the CSS property or INI key.
  • Ensure you’re editing the GTK3 configuration directory (~/.config/gtk-3.0/).

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text: • These settings do not affect web-page text fields in browsers; those are rendered by the browser engine itself.

docs.title: GTK2 Support
docs.text:
For GTK2 applications, add overrides to your ~/.gtkrc-2.0 file:

# ~/.gtkrc-2.0
style "custom-caret-textview" {
    GtkTextView::cursor_aspect_ratio = 0.1
    # try 0.05, 0.1, or 0.2 for different thickness
}
widget_class "*TextView*" style "custom-caret-textview"

style "custom-caret-entry" {
    GtkEntry::cursor_aspect_ratio = 0.1
}
widget_class "*Entry*" style "custom-caret-entry"

Save and restart any GTK2 apps (e.g., Gedit, Leafpad) to see the thicker caret immediately.

Here are commands and comments details the process:

# 1. Obtain the Process ID of the XFCE4 Panel

# 2. Kill the Panel using the PID obtained

killall xfce4-panel
# 2. Restart the XFCE4 Panel (Background)

# 3. Finally release from current terminal session
disown

docs.title: SSH Login
docs.text:
Reference Video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xVW1fGRlRkE

ssh <cred>

On the Remote Machine:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:yubico/stable
...
sudo apt install libpam-yubico # For Yubikey Auth

Edit the config in Remote Machine:

sudo nano /etc/ssh/authorized_yubikeys
...
# Add a Line
<userID>:<first12chars-short-press-yubikey>
# Save the file after this
Generate API Key:

https://upgrade.yubico.com/getapikey

Enter you Email Address. In YubiKey OTP short press the button to enter text. Check the Box for terms and press Get API Key.

It would give the <CLIENT ID> and <Secret Key>.

Edit the SSH Config on Remote Machine:

sudo nano /etc/pam.d/sshd
...
# Add a line at the Opt of the file
auth required pam_yubico.so id=<CLIENT ID> KEY=<Secret Key> authfile=/etc/ssh/authorized_yubikeys
## Save tje File with this

Edit the SSHD config in Remote Machine:

sudo nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config
...
PasswordAuthentication no
...
ChallengeResponseAuthentication yes
...
UsePAM yes
## Save the File
Restart the SSH Service on the Remote Machine: 
sudo systemctl restart ssh

docs.title: Enable SSH on Stick PC
docs.text:
On Target PC:

# Set Keymap
loadkeys us
WiFi Configuration 
We would use the 'iw' Shell
 iwctl <- Command is used to activate this shell

For the default 'wlan0' adapter we would use the following commands
 [iwd]# station wlan0 scan
 [iwd]# station wlan0 get-networks
 [iwd]# station wlan0 connect <your-desired-accesspoint-name>
 [iwd]# station wlan0 show
 [iwd]# exit

Set Password for root user:

passwd

Once this is set, you have default SSH enabled so this Target PC is ready for connection.

Find out your IP address

ip -c a
Here -c will just add the color the IP address shown.

docs.title: Update Repositories
docs.text:
# Setup NTP
timedatectl set-ntp true
# Reflector update
reflector \
    --country India,Singapore,Japan,'South Korea' \
    --age 6 \
    --protocol https \
    --sort rate \
    --save /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist
# System Update
pacman -Syyy

docs.title: Drive Format
docs.text:
We had an internal EMMC and SD card both of 32GB. So decided the following structure:

Partition Type Size Mount Location EMMC partition 1 UEFI +200M /mnt/boot/efi EMMC partition 2 Root with rest of the space /mnt SD Card partition 1 Swap +9.4GB swap SD Card partition 2 Home with rest of the space /mnt/home

docs.title: Begin Install
docs.text:
pacstrap /mnt base linux-lts linux-firmware vim intel-ucode bash-completion
It had an Intel CPU hence intel-ucode and for easier typing bash-completion. 
genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab

Creating the Filesystem mount table.

Now enter the new system:

arch-chroot /mnt

Setup the basic things:

# Setup NTP
timedatectl set-ntp true
# Set the Correct time Zone
ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Asia/Kolkata /etc/localtime
# Synchronize the clock
hwclock --systohc

Locale settings: 

# Edit current locale - Uncomment the line en_US.UTF-8
vim /etc/locale.gen
# Generate
locale-gen
# Edit Locale config
vim /etc/locale.conf
# Add the line `LANG=en_US.UTF-8`

Set Host name and Networking: 

echo -n 'arch-iot' > /etc/hostname
echo "\n127.0.0.1\tlocalhost" >> /etc/hosts
echo "::1\t\tlocalhost" >> /etc/hosts
echo "127.0.1.1\tarch-iot.localdomain\tarch-iot" >> /etc/hosts

Set the Root password of the system: 

passwd

Install remaining utilities: 

pacman -S reflector grub efibootmgr networkmanager network-manager-applet \
 mtools dosfstools base-devel linux-headers git xdg-utils xdg-user-dirs \
 ufw nano nano-syntax-highlighting vim-airline

Fix the Boot sequence for headless booting:

vim /etc/mkinitcpio.conf

Find the HOOK= and make it looks like this:

HOOKS=(base udev block keyboard autodetect modconf kms keymap consolefont filesystems fsck)

Finally regenerate the system:

mkinitcpio -p linux-lts

Next, install grub:

grub-install --target=x86_64-efi --efi-directory=/boot/efi --bootloader-id=GRUB --recheck

# Generate Grub configuration
grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg

docs.title: Enable Services
docs.text:
systemctl enable NetworkManager
# Don't enable ufw for now till the reboot

docs.title: Create the user for the System
docs.text:
useradd -m -g users \
    -G wheel,storage,rfkill,power,lp,lock,uucp \
    -s /bin/bash \
    <UserName>
passwd <UserName>

Add the User permission as sudo: 

vim /etc/sudoers.d/<UserName>
# Add the Line
# <UserName> ALL=(ALL) ALL
# For No password once logged in you can have
# <UserName> ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWORD: ALL

Fix wheel Group Permissions : 

EDITOR=vim visudo
# Uncomment the line
# "%wheel ALL=(ALL:ALL) ALL"

docs.title: End
docs.text:
# Exit the Chroot
exit
# Unmount all drives
umount -a

Reboot the system to enter into the new Arch installation.

docs.title: V1 First Install Attempt
docs.text:
The full installation can be divided into 4 main Phases.

  1. Setup and partitioning which would include the boot-strapping the install of the Root file system.

  2. Chroot environment during installation where basic packages are installed and the boot-loader is configured. This also includes the creation of a user.

  3. This is the time when the other system packages are installed along with the desktop environment.

  4. Finally tunning of the system and installation of the non-default drivers.

docs.title: 1. Set the Correct Font for the console so that its easier to see
docs.text:
Set a better font. 

setfont sun12x22.psfu.gz

For even bigger fonts: 

setfont solar24x32.psfu.gz

If terminus-font is already install like in the default Arch-iso you can use: 

setfont ter-132n

docs.title: 2. Configure default Keymap
docs.text:
Search for US Keyboads: 

localectl list-keymaps | grep us
Output: 
...
us
us-acentos
us1
...
Set the Correct layout: 
loadkeys us

docs.title: 3. Configure the Wireless
docs.text:
Enter the iw shell: 

iwctl
Inside the iw shell Commands for wlan0 WiFi Adapter 
[iwd]# station wlan0 scan
[iwd]# station wlan0 get-networks
Now you will get the list of networks available. In our case it is wifiaccesspoint. We connect to it. 
[iwd]# station wlan0 connect wifiaccesspoint
You would be asked password for the selected network. To check if the connection was made 
[iwd]# station wlan0 show
Once you are satisfied, exit the iw shell. 
[iwd]# exit

docs.title: 4. Check if we are Online
docs.text:
We try to Ping the archlinux.org server 2 times. 

ping -c 2 archlinux.org
If you get the ok result then you have successfully connected to Internet.

In case you wish to further debug use the ip tool: 

ip addr show
Or simply 
ip a

docs.title: 5. (Optional) Setup NTP for Time and Date synchronization
docs.text:
This is optional but would help you in some later stages. Enable NTP: 

timedatectl set-ntp true
Check if the Correct time is being reported : 
timedatectl status
Note: The time and date here would be reported in UTC time. Hence you would need your phone or some other computer connected to internet to verify the time shown.

docs.title: 6. Configure the Repository Mirrors
docs.text:
We would configure https mirrors for 3 countries - India, United States and Japan; with maximum update age of 6 Hours and sorted by their rate: 

reflector --country 'United States',Japan,India --age 6 \
 --protocol https --sort rate --save /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist

Now to update the pacman repository: 

pacman -Syy

To check if our mirror list indeed got updated: 

cat /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist

docs.title: 7. Partition the Disk
docs.text:
We would use 2 partitions - Root and home.

First we check the disk status: 

lsblk
Find out the correct disk ID we are looking to work on.

In our case we have /dev/sda Let's start the partition program: 

cfdisk /dev/sda
Perform the Partition to obtain correct sizes of Root and home partitions.

Confirm if the partitions are written to disk : 

lsblk
In our case the configuration states that we have: - Root is in /dev/sda5 - home is in /dev/sda6

docs.title: 8. Formatting the Partitions
docs.text:
Format the Root partition: 

mkfs.ext4 /dev/sda5
Next Format the home partition: 
mkfs.ext4 /dev/sda6
Swap is not needed since we have enough RAM to support us.

docs.title: 9. Mounting the Partitions correctly
docs.text:
Mount the Main Root partition: 

mount /dev/sda5 /mnt
Create the directory for boot partition in our case a UEFI system and mount the same: 
mkdir /mnt/boot
mount /dev/sda2 /mnt/boot
Create the directory for home partitions and mount it: 
mkdir /mnt/home
mount /dev/sda6 /mnt/home
Check the Mount points of the system to confirm if everything is alright: 
lsblk

docs.title: 10. Bootstrap the Installation for Root File system
docs.text:
We use pacstrap to create the Root file system and install some minimum things - including a editor like vim: 

pacstrap /mnt base linux linux-firmware vim

docs.title: 11. Write the FSTAB file for correct mounting of drives
docs.text:
Check if we still have the correct mounting: 

lsblk
Generate the FSTAB file: 
genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab

docs.title: 12. Finally progress to Stage 2 by CHROOT
docs.text:
Enter the installation Root File System: 

arch-chroot /mnt

docs.title: 1. Set the Timezone correctly
docs.text:
Find the required timezone in our case Kolkata: 

timedatectl list-timezones | grep Kolkata
Next set the correct zone: 
ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Asia/Kolkata /etc/localtime
Now update the Hardware clocks: 
hwclock --systohc
You can verify that the clocks are indeed set right: 
date

docs.title: 2. Fix the Locale and keyboard
docs.text:
Configure the Locale for UTF-8 with US and IN: 

echo "## Edited" >> /etc/locale.gen
echo "en_US.UTF-8 UTF-8" >> /etc/locale.gen
echo "en_IN UTF-8" >> /etc/locale.gen
or edit vim /etc/locale.gen and add the lines 
## Edited
en_US.UTF-8 UTF-8
en_IN UTF-8
Next Add the Configuration for Language US and Localization to IN. 
vim /etc/locale.conf
Add the Lines: 
LANG=en_US.UTF-8
LC_ADDRESS=en_IN
LC_IDENTIFICATION=en_IN
LC_MEASUREMENT=en_IN
LC_MONETARY=en_IN
LC_NAME=en_IN
LC_NUMERIC=en_IN
LC_PAPER=en_IN
LC_TELEPHONE=en_IN
LC_TIME=en_IN

Next Configure the Keymap to IN for English keyboard with Rupee symbol. 

echo "KEYMAP=in" > /etc/vconsole.conf

docs.title: 3. Generate the Localization
docs.text:
Generate the Locale: 

locale-gen

docs.title: 4. Configure the Host name
docs.text:
We chose the host name to be arch1. 

echo "arch1" > /etc/hostname
Edit the hosts file : 
vim /etc/hosts
Add the lines with Tab as separator: 
127.0.0.1   localhost
::1         localhost
127.0.1.1   arch1.localdomain  arch1

docs.title: 5. Set Root User password
docs.text:
Create a password for the Root user: 

passwd
Make sure to use 2 passwords one for Root and a different one for the normal user which we create later.

docs.title: 6. Install the Boot requirements
docs.text:
Install the basic boot & Network utilities and services: 

pacman -Syu grub efibootmgr os-prober ntfs-3g mtools dosfstools exfatprogs \
 networkmanager dialog base-devel linux-headers bash bash-completion nano \
 bluez bluez-tools pulseaudio-bluetooth cups git reflector \
 xdg-utils xdg-user-dirs openssh acpi wget

docs.title: 7. Install the Boot-loader and Configure
docs.text:
We would be using GRUB and its auto-generated configuration: 

grub-install --target=x86_64-efi --efi-directory=/boot --bootloader-id=GRUB
Next run the command to generate the configuration: 
grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
Make sure to check if all the operating systems are detected here.

docs.title: 8. Enable Essential Services
docs.text:
We use systemd to enable the required services: 

systemctl enable NetworkManager
systemctl enable bluetooth
systemctl enable org.cups.cupsd

docs.title: 9. Create assign groups to the Normal user
docs.text:
We have chosen the name archer for our user: 

useradd -m -g users -G wheel,storage,power,lp,lock,uucp -s /bin/bash archer
Next we set a password for the user: 
passwd archer

docs.title: 10. Give the wheel group sudo permissions
docs.text:
We need to open the permissions in editor: 

EDITOR=vim visudo
Just scroll and un-comment the line %wheel ALL=(ALL) ALL.

docs.title: 11. Move to the Next stage
docs.text:
We come to the end of the 2nd stage of installation. First we move out the chroot environment. 

exit
Next we unmount all the volumes. 
umount -a
Finally we reboot the computer. 
reboot

docs.title: Stage 3 Commands
docs.text: After we reboot, we can select Arch Linux in the GRUB menu. This would drop us to the text login prompt. Where we can login using archer user name and the password we set earlier.

docs.title: 1. Connect to the Internet
docs.text:
We would have to use a different tool now NetworkManager: 

nmtui
This is text based gui driven, so should be easy to connect. Next, we verify if we are indeed connected. 
ping -c 2 archlinux.org

docs.title: 2. Verify that we still have our secure Repositories
docs.text:
Check the list of mirrors: 

cat /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist
If we still find it incorrect then run the reflector command again: 
reflector --country 'United States',Japan,India --age 6 \
 --protocol https --sort rate --save /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist

docs.title: 3. (Optional) Fix the console font
docs.text:
This is same way we did earlier: 

setfont sun12x22.psfu.gz

docs.title: 4. Install the XFCE Desktop Environment Packages
docs.text:
First we need to update pacman: 

sudo pacman -Syu
Install the Display driver for Basic Intel mother board and NVIDIA graphics card: 
sudo pacman -S xf86-video-intel xf86-video-nouveau
In case you wish to have the non-free version of the NVIDIA drivers use packages nvidia and nvidia-utils. For other type of GPUs use the following - xf86-video-amdgpu, xf86-video-ati, xf86-video-vesa ; these correspond to AMD CPU+GPU combo, ATI Graphics cards and Older VESA supporting cards, respectively.

Next we install the Desktop Environment and its utilities: 

sudo pacman -S xorg xf86-input-libinput libinput xfce4 xfce4-goodies \
 xfce4-sensors-plugin archlinux-xdg-menu lightdm lightdm-gtk-greeter \
 pavucontrol gvfs firefox udisks2 udiskie udevil xarchiver p7zip usbutils \
 cups-pdf libcups system-config-printer blueman ufw ipset ebtables \
 p7zip network-manager-applet youtube-dl

docs.title: 5. Enable Important Services
docs.text:
Configure the GUI environment again using systemd: 

sudo systemctl enable ufw
sudo systemctl enable lightdm
If you are using SSD for the install then you also need to enable the fstrim: 
sudo systemctl enable fstrim.service
sudo systemctl enable fstrim.timer
In case you don't find the fstrim service just install sudo pacman -S util-linux.

docs.title: 6. Adding some Essential XFCE utilities
docs.text:
Here is the sundry list of utilities: 

sudo pacman -S firefox lm_sensors keepassxc qpdfview pdfarranger zbar qtqr \
 xsane featherpad notepadqq telegram-desktop nomacs vlc libreoffice hunspell \
 hunspell-en_US languagetool keychain gnome-keyring seahorse \
 hddtemp smartmontools tree patch tmux veracrypt htop hyphen-en libmythes \
 mythes-en gitg meld arch-audit gufw

Additionally we would need some good fonts packages (Nearly 1.5GB): 

sudo pacman -S ttf-droid gnu-free-fonts noto-fonts noto-fonts-extra \
 ttf-caladea ttf-carlito ttf-cascadia-code ttf-cormorant ttf-croscore \
 ttf-dejavu ttf-eurof ttf-fira-code ttf-fira-mono ttf-fira-sans \
 ttf-hack ttf-inconsolata ttf-indic-otf ttf-ionicons ttf-jetbrains-mono \
 ttf-junicode ttf-khmer ttf-lato ttf-joypixels ttf-ibm-plex ttf-hannom \
 ttf-hanazono ttf-liberation ttf-linux-libertine ttf-linux-libertine-g \
 ttf-monofur ttf-nerd-fonts-symbols ttf-opensans ttf-proggy-clean \
 ttf-roboto ttf-roboto-mono ttf-sazanami ttf-tibetan-machine \

docs.title: 8. Configure the AUR download tool
docs.text:
We would be using paru tool. Here are its dependencies: 

sudo pacman -S --needed base-devel
We would build it in the temporary location: 
cd /tmp
git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/paru.git
cd paru
makepkg -si
You would be asked permission and sudo password entry for installation.

docs.text:
We are done with the things for this stage. 

reboot

docs.title: Stage 4 Commands
docs.text: Now you would be greeted in lightdm environment. You can login with the same archer user. Open a Terminal for the next set of commands.

docs.title: 1. (Optional) Network connection Check
docs.text:
In the Terminal: 

nmtui

docs.title: 2. Install the AUR Packages
docs.text:
We need a few essential packages from AUR. We would be installing them using paru tool that we installed earlier. 

paru xfce4-kbdleds-plugin
paru caffeine-ng
sudo ufw enable
Additionally install the languagetool extension for LibreOffice from https://languagetool.org/#libreoffice.

Also make sure to add nm-applet to the Session and Startup else Wifi Icon, would not be visible.

IMPORTANT: Also make Enable Launch GNOME services on startup in Advance Tab of the Session and Startup. This would allow the ssh and gpg services to have a nice Password GUI and maintain credentials over the session.

docs.title: 3. Fix Bluetooth tools
docs.text:
We need to remove a few things first: 

sudo pacman -R bluez-utils
sudo pacman -R bluez-hcitool
sudo pacman -R bluez-rfcomm
Next we install the AUR packages for the fixes: 
paru bluez-rfcomm
paru bluez-hcitool
paru bluez-utils-compat

docs.title: 4. Install Driver for TP-Link Archer T9UH V2 USB dongle WiFi adapter
docs.text:
We need DKMS for this driver. 

sudo pacman -Syu
sudo pacman -S dkms
paru rtl8814au-aircrack-dkms-git
More information about this from - https://aur.archlinux.org/rtl8814au-aircrack-dkms-git.git

docs.title: 5. Install Driver for Brother Printer HL-L2321D
docs.text:
Download the Linux DEB file driver from the Brother Support website. It should be a file like linux-brprinter-installer-2.2.2-1.gz Un-archive it into a folder.

Install this driver's dependencies and add current user to new group lpadmin: 

sudo pacman -S dpkg lib32-glibc
sudo groupadd lpadmin
sudo usermod -aG lpadmin $USER

Change into the directory where the printer driver is extracted. 

chmod +x linux-brprinter-installer-2.2.2-1
Note While performing the Installation make sure not to select the URI.

As per Brother driver Documentation:

Step7. The driver installation will start. Follow the installation screen directions. When you see the message "Will you specify the DeviceURI ?",

For USB Users: Choose N(No) For Network Users: Choose Y(Yes) and DeviceURI number.

The install process may take some time. Please wait until it is complete.

Give command for installation: 

sudo ./linux-brprinter-installer-2.2.2-1 HL-L2321D

docs.title: Alternate Install - i3
docs.text:
# Window Manager - To start from command-line we need `xorg-xinit`
sudo pacman -S xorg xorg-xinit
# I3 packages
# * i3-wm = I3 window manager
# * i3lock = Improved screenlocker based upon XCB and PAM
# * i3status = Status bar at the Bottom of the screen
# * i3blocks = Define blocks for your i3bar status line
# * dmenu = For the Run Menu operation to select programs start
# * terminator = Terminal
sudo pacman -S i3-wm i3lock i3status i3blocks dmenu terminator firefox

Copy the Xinit file into home directory: 

sudo cp /etc/X11/xinit/xinitrc ~/.xinitrc
# edit this file
sudo vim ~/.xinitrc
#
# Delete last few lines containing `-geometry`.
#
# Add the following line to end of the .xinitrc
#
# exec i3
#
# And save the file

Start I3 using: 

startx

Press Enter if the Config is being created the first time.

  • Set <Win> as the default modifier key and press Enter
  • There might be an error after this step. Dont worry open the configuration for edit. Find the location for dmenu using search. There would be 2 options enabled for same d key. Try to change Comment the one with the bare dmenu command since it directly catches the command name. The other i3 based dmenu is better.

Command:

  • Mod {Win} + Enter = Terminal prompt
  • xrandr --output Virtual-1 --mode 1920x1080 = This would make display in VM equal to full screen.
  • Mod {Win} + Shift + q = Quit application
  • Mod {Win} + v = For Vertical Tiling begining
  • Mod {Win} + h = For Horizontal Tiling begin
  • Mod {Win} + s = Stack Mode
  • Mod {Win} + e = Tiling Mode
  • Mod {Win} + w = Tab Mode
  • Mod {Win} + r = resize Mode Use Left and Right arrow keys
  • Mod {Win} = Use Arrow keys to move around windows
  • Mod {Win} + Shift = Arrow keys can be used to move the windows left or right
  • Mod {Win} + 1 to 9 = To switch the other workspaces
  • Mod {Win} + Shift + 1 to 9 = Move window to other workspace
  • Mod {Win} + d = For Dmenu to come up
  • Mod {Win} + Shift + r = To resetart the I3 compositor
  • Mod {Win} + Shift + e = To exit I3 and return to lightDM or commandline.

Config (end of the file):

# Keybaord Layout - Always runs when the config reloads
exec_always setxkbmap -model pc105 -layout in -variant eng
# Display Resolution of VM
exec_always xrandr --output Virtual-1 --mode 1920x180

Keyboard Config for India: 

$ cat /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/00-keyboard.conf
# Read and parsed by systemd-localed. It's probably wise not to edit this file
# manually too freely.
Section "InputClass"
        Identifier "system-keyboard"
        MatchIsKeyboard "on"
        Option "XkbLayout" "in"
        Option "XkbModel" "pc105"
        Option "XkbVariant" "eng"
EndSection

pacman -Syyy

docs.title: 2.7 - Partition Disk
docs.text:
Get Disks:

lsblk

For VM: 

gdisk /dev/vda

For Normal: 

gdisk /dev/sda

n - for New Partition

Partition Order for 8GB RAM:

No . Partition Size Code 1 /boot +512M (511MByte) ef00 2 Swap +9G (8.5GByte) 8200 3 /dev/mapper/cryptroot Rest of Capacity 8300

w - Write Changes to Disk

lsblk

docs.text:

mkfs.fat -F32 /dev/vda1

mkswap /dev/vda2

swapon /dev/vda2

Create Encryption for Root filesystem - type YES: 

cryptsetup -y -v luksFormat /dev/vda3

Open the LUKS filesystem: 

cryptsetup open /dev/vda3 cryptroot

Format the Mounted LUKS filesystem: 

mkfs.ext4 /dev/mapper/cryptroot

docs.title: Arch Linux Installation Version 21
docs.text:
Yes, that many incomplete and failed attempts.

Following the Instructions from

https://www.learnlinux.tv/arch-linux-full-installation-guide/

Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DPLnBPM4DhI

Strangely this install finished without a problem. Though the final GUI was crude but functional.

Most important there was a sense of understanding of what was needed to fix and add more functionality.

Installed started on 00:30 30-October-2023. Literally middle of the night for us here.

And completed around 01:15 30-October-2023. Not bad for the 21st attempt.

docs.title: Internet
docs.text:
Using the iw Shell iwctl Command.

For the default wlan0 adapter commands:

 [iwd]# station wlan0 scan
 [iwd]# station wlan0 get-networks
 [iwd]# station wlan0 connect <your-desired-accesspoint-name>
 [iwd]# station wlan0 show
 [iwd]# exit

docs.title: Time Configuration
docs.text:
timedatectl set-ntp true
timedatectl set-timezone "Asia\Kolkata"

docs.title: Partition setup
docs.text:
List the Disks

fdisk -l

Layout:

  1. EFI 512MiB
  2. Root 120GiB LVM Partition
  3. No Swap as would use a File for the same

More details about LVM are documented here.

Setup of LVM:

 pvcreate --dataalignment 1m /dev/<DEVICE NAME>
 vgcreate volgroup0 /dev/<DEVICE NAME>
 lvcreate -L 60GB volgroup0 -n lv_root
 lvcreate -l 100%FREE volgroup0 -n lv_home
 modprobe dm_mod
 vgscan
 vgchange -ay

We will mount the Boot partition later only format it.

mkfs.fat -F32 /dev/<EFI-DEVICE>

Format & Mount the Partitions:

mkfs.ext4 /dev/volgroup0/lv_root
mount /dev/volgroup0/lv_root /mnt
mkfs.ext4 /dev/volgroup0/lv_home
mkdir /mnt/home
mount /dev/volgroup0/lv_home /mnt/home

docs.title: Create fstab
docs.text:
Here we have a new way to create fstab file even before the system is available.

mkdir /mnt/etc
genfstab -U -p /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab

Check It:

cat /mnt/etc/fstab

docs.title: Begin Installation of Arch
docs.text:
No more update to package list needed.

pacstrap -i /mnt base

Enter the System:

arch-chroot /mnt

Install Kernel and headers:

pacman -S linux linux-headers linux-lts linux-lts-headers
pacman -S nano bash-completion terminus-font
pacman -S base-devel openssh
systemctl enable sshd

We install both Kernels and their headers.

We have added a few more ancillary packages to help us with the work.

Some more networking packages:

pacman -S networkmanager wpa_supplicant wireless_tools netctl
pacman -S dialog
systemctl enable NetworkManager

Install LVM Support:

pacman -S lvm2

We would need to add the LVM to load at boot:

nano /etc/mkinitcpio.conf

Add lvm2 after block in HOOKS= line.

Rebuild the configs:

mkinitcpio -p linux
mkinitcpio -p linux-lts

Since we installed both we need to build for both.

Finally its time for editing the Locale:

nano /etc/locale.gen

Uncomment en_US.UTF-8 line.

Generate the Locale:

locale-gen

We create password for root user and add a PC user as well. This would be helpful later.

passwd
useradd -m -g users -G wheel <USERNAME>
passwd <USERNAME>

Edit the sudo permissions:

EDITOR=nano visudo
Uncomment the %wheel ALL=(ALL... line.

Finally installing bootloader stuff:

pacman -S grub efibootmgr dosfstools os-prober mtools

Let's mound our Boot partition now:

mkdir /boot/EFI
mount /dev/<EFI-DEVICE> /boot/EFI

It's late but much better this way.

Install the bootloader:

grub-install --target=x86_64-efi --bootloader-id=GRUB_UEFI --recheck

If this does not work check for locale directory ls -l /boo/grub.

Else create it mkdir /boo/grub/locale.

Fix the locale:

cp /usr/share/locale/en\@quot/LC_MESSAGES/grub.mo /boot/grub/locale/en.mo
Don't worry about the strange /en\@quot/ its correct !

Finally generate the Grub config.

grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg

Exit the chroot and power off to remove the boot media:

exit
umount -a
poweroff

Now Restart the computer.

docs.title: Boot into fresh Arch Linux OS for First time
docs.text:
Login using the <USERNAME> we created earlier.

Don't worry about internet as its not needed immediately.

Become the super user, here where your root password is needed.

su

We first need the SWAP 2GiB file:

dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1M count=2048 status=progress
chmod 600 /swapfile
mkswap /swapfile

Let's add this to the fstab safely:

cp /etc/fstab /etc/fstab.bak
echo '/swapfile none swap sw 0 0' | tee -a /etc/fstab
mount -a
swapon -a

Now to check SWAP:

free -m

It should show the new 2GiB swap added there.

Now let's work on the time:

timedatectl set-timezone "Asia/Kolkata"
timedatectl set-ntp true
systemctl enable systemd-timesyncd

Name your Computer:

hostnamectl set-hostname <SYSTEM-NAME>

Let's fix the host file for networking:

nano /etc/hosts

Edit the file so that it looks like this:

# Static table lookup for hostnames.
# See hosts(5) for details.
127.0.0.1 localhost
127.0.1.1 <SYSTEM-NAME>

Finally reboot the computer again.

docs.title: Second Boot into the System
docs.text:
Login using the <USERNAME> we created earlier.

Become the root user:

su

Setup the network this time.

nmtui

Install essential UCODE and firmware:

pacman -S intel-ucode
pacman -S linux-firmware sof-firmware

For AMD chips use amd-ucode.

Rebuild the configuration:

mkinitcpio -p linux
mkinitcpio -p linux-lts

Finally reboot again for the configuration to take effect.

docs.title: Third Boot into the System
docs.text:
Login using the <USERNAME> we created earlier.

Become the root user:

su

This time the internet should work properly.

Secure the sshd using its configuration file:

nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config

Restart the sshd:

systemctl restart sshd

Install another editor vim:

pacman -S bash-completion vim vim-airline

Finally install the X interface:

pacman -S xorg-server

We need to install the correct graphics driver:

  • This is for processor built In AMD or Intel GPU

    pacman -S mesa
    - For NVIDIA 
    pacman -S nvidia nvidia-lts

  • For VirtualBox VM

    pacman -S virtualbox-guest-utils xf86-video-vmware
systemctl enable vboxservice

    Don't worry the vmware part is ok.

Finally reboot again for the graphics drivers to take effect.

docs.title: Fourth Boot into the System
docs.text:
Login using the <USERNAME> we created earlier.

Become the root user:

su

We fix the Console fonts:

vim /etc/vconsole.conf

Add the line FONT=ter-132b. This would enable proper boot fonts.

Finally reboot the computer again to check.

docs.title: Fifth Boot into the System
docs.text:
Login using the <USERNAME> we created earlier.

Become the root user:

su

Finally we install the XFCE:

pacman -S xfce4 xfce4-goodies
pacman -S lightdm lightdm-gtk-greeter
systemctl enable lightdm

This is the last time to reboot.

You will next be greeted by the light-dm login screen.

There is a need to reorganize this but it was nice that the whole thing worked without much of troubles.

docs.title: 1. Correction to Fail to Lockout File
docs.text:
Do this WITHOUT INTERNET

Need to change the # deny = 3 todeny = 5. It is in Line 32 or so.

docs.title: 2. Configure Pacman Mirror Fetch
docs.text:
Do this WITHOUT INTERNET

sudo nano /etc/pacman-mirrors.conf

Need to change Line 22 to Protocols = https And Line 27 or Last line to SSLVerify = True

Quick Replace script:

# Switch the Protocol to HTTPS
sudo sed -i 's/# Protocols =/Protocols = https/g' /etc/pacman-mirrors.conf
# Enable SSL Certificate Verification
sudo sed -i 's/# SSLVerify/SSLVerify/g' /etc/pacman-mirrors.conf

docs.title: 3. Add Support for AUR and other Config options to pamac
docs.text:
Do this WITHOUT INTERNET

Edit the pamac config file: 

sudo nano /etc/pamac.conf

Edit the following: 

## When removing a package, also remove those dependencies
## that are not required by other packages (recurse option):
RemoveUnrequiredDeps

## How often to check for updates, value in hours (0 to disable):
RefreshPeriod = 24

## When no update is available, hide the tray icon:
NoUpdateHideIcon

## When applying updates, enable packages downgrade:
EnableDowngrade

...

## Allow Pamac to search and install packages from AUR:
EnableAUR

...

## When AUR support is enabled check for updates from AUR:
CheckAURUpdates

...

## AUR build directory:
BuildDirectory = /var/tmp

## Number of versions of each package to keep when cleaning the packages cache:
KeepNumPackages = 1

...

## Maximum Parallel Downloads:
MaxParallelDownloads = 8

...

This would update both the GUI and the Command line.

NOT CORRECT following the Single User Nix install process
docs.text:
Incorrect way as per Rajiv

https://nixos.org/download

Single-user installation :

https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/installation/single-user

sh <(curl -L https://nixos.org/nix/install) --no-daemon
Got: 
Installation finished!  To ensure that the necessary environment
variables are set, either log in again, or type

. /home/user/.nix-profile/etc/profile.d/nix.sh

in your shell.

nix-channel --list
nixpkgs https://nixos.org/channels/nixpkgs-unstable

docs.title: Modded Rajiv's Nix bootstrap with new Nix Install Process
docs.text:
His original work:

https://github.com/rajivr/bootstrap-minimal-nix

More reference to that below.

It was concluded that the mistake in process shown in the NixOS website was:

Need to Use --no-daemon --no-channel-add --no-modify-profile instead of just --no-daemon.

Instead we would like to directly install nix-2.18.1:

https://releases.nixos.org/?prefix=nix/nix-2.18.1/

Here is how we go about it:

  1. Getting Nix for Manjaro:

    mkdir /tmp/nix-install
cd /tmp/nix-install
curl -LO https://releases.nixos.org/nix/nix-2.18.1/nix-2.18.1-x86_64-linux.tar.xz
tar xvf nix-2.18.1-x86_64-linux.tar.xz

  2. Installation of Nix in Manjaro:

    cd /tmp/nix-install
cd nix-2.18.1-x86_64-linux
./install --no-daemon --no-channel-add --no-modify-profile

    Output of the Installation Process:

    installing 'nix-2.18.1'
building '/nix/store/hzx954rnda4k348rb4wvqbdzp9z0ynjy-user-environment.drv'...

Installation finished!  To ensure that the necessary environment
variables are set, please add the line

. /home/user/.nix-profile/etc/profile.d/nix.sh

to your shell profile (e.g. ~/.profile).

  3. Cleanup after install is completed:

    cd ../..
rm -rf nix-install

  4. Next Enable flakes Feature:

    mkdir $HOME/.config/nix
echo "experimental-features = nix-command flakes" >> $HOME/.config/nix/nix.conf

  5. Now after Reboot activate the Environment:

    . /home/user/.nix-profile/etc/profile.d/nix.sh

Easy!! you now have Nix without channels and supporting the Flakes feature.

docs.title: Script for Automation
docs.text:
#!/bin/sh

mkdir /tmp/nix-install
cd /tmp/nix-install
curl -LO https://hydra.nixos.org/build/128347132/download/1/nix-3.0pre20201007_5257a25-x86_64-linux.tar.xz

tar xvf nix-3.0pre20201007_5257a25-x86_64-linux.tar.xz

cd nix-3.0pre20201007_5257a25-x86_64-linux/
./install --no-daemon --no-channel-add --no-modify-profile
cd ..
rm -rf nix*

cd


mkdir $HOME/.config/nix
echo "experimental-features = nix-command flakes" >> $HOME/.config/nix/nix.conf

curl -LO https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/archive/refs/tags/21.05.tar.gz
git clone --depth 1 --branch release-21.05 https://github.com/nix-community/home-manager.git

tar -xf 21.05.tar.gz

echo "source $HOME/.nix-profile/etc/profile.d/nix.sh" >> ~/.bashrc
echo "export NIX_PATH=\"nixpkgs=${HOME}/nixpkgs-21.05:home-manager=${HOME}/home-manager\"" >> ~/.bashrc

echo
echo
echo " Make sure to Log-out and Login again after installation "
echo

Make sure to follow the Login - Logout cycle after this so that the new config gets activated.

su nix-user

docs.title: Creating Local nixpkgs
docs.text:
The Problem with #Rajiv 's tutorial is that its more local. Hence we don't necessary have access to nixpkgs

In nix-pills following chapter 6, we would get into trouble without this.

docs.title: Get the Current Version of nixpkgs
docs.text:
Get the Current Version of the Nix Channel build for nixos-21.05:

curl -Ls -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.v3.sha" "https://api.github.com/repos/NixOS/nixpkgs/commits/nixos-21.05"

Here the last part at .../commits/nixos-21.05 is the place we need to add future versions if needed.

This command would give the following output: 

63ee5cd99a2e193d5e4c879feb9683ddec23fa03

This is the commit hash. Hence our download path becomes: https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/archive/63ee5cd99a2e193d5e4c879feb9683ddec23fa03.tar.gz

docs.title: Get the SHA256 Hash required by nix-build
docs.text:
To get the SH256 Hash Correctly:

nix-prefetch-url --unpack --print-path https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/archive/63ee5cd99a2e193d5e4c879feb9683ddec23fa03.tar.gz

It would give the output 

unpacking...
0avbsx5chbwr0y55shndkzf0ixx3bznbzq526p5nj8llryxa10af
/nix/store/k48nwi5676v70la1by8vhqb7p8551c9d-63ee5cd99a2e193d5e4c879feb9683ddec23fa03.tar.gz

The second line is the SHA256 Hash needed by nix build.

We might optionally cleanup the nix-store before we proceed:

nix-store --gc

docs.title: Create the nixpkgs.nix for System build
docs.text:
Now in order to have a location for nixpkgs we need to first create a .nix for nix-build.

cd ~
nano nixpkgs.nix

Note that this would be in our nix-user $HOME directory.

Here is whats should be written to nixpkgs.nix:

let
  nixpkgs = fetchTarball {
    url = "https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/archive/63ee5cd99a2e193d5e4c879feb9683ddec23fa03.tar.gz";
    sha256 = "0avbsx5chbwr0y55shndkzf0ixx3bznbzq526p5nj8llryxa10af";
  };
  pkgs = import nixpkgs {};
in
  pkgs.runCommandNoCC "nixpkgs-stable" {} ''
    ln -s ${nixpkgs} $out
  ''

Note the URL Path and SHA256 Hash in the content. This would change with revisions.

Next we need to create a script to perform the nix-build.

This script would be called sync.sh:

#!/usr/bin/env bash

set -e
set -u
PS4=" $ "

unset NIX_PATH

set -x

nix-build "./nixpkgs.nix" --out-link "nixpkgs"

Make sure the get the sync.sh as Executable. And run the same.

docs.title: Update NIX_PATH variable
docs.text:
We would need to edit our .bashrc to add this variable.

Add the line at the end of .bashrc:

source ~/.nix-profile/etc/profile.d/nix.sh

export NIX_PATH="nixpkgs=$HOME/nixpkgs"

These would always keep the nix-user ready in the nix space.
