docs.title: Details
docs.text: The head command prints the first lines (10 lines by default) of one or more files or piped data to standard output.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/aix/7.2?topic=files-displaying-first-lines-head-command
  • https://linuxize.com/post/linux-head-command/
  • https://superuser.com/a/470957 - Random Data file generation

docs.title: Command Syntax
docs.text:
head [OPTION]... [FILE]...
  • OPTION - The most common options in the next sections.
  • FILE - Zero or more input file names. If no FILE is specified, or when FILE is -, head will read the standard input / pipe.

docs.title: First 10 lines or Default - No options
docs.text:
head filename.txt

In its simplest form, when used without any option. The head command displays the first 10 lines.

docs.title: Display a Specific Number of Lines
docs.text:
head -n <NUMBER> filename.txt
Use the -n (--lines) option followed by an integer <NUMBER> specifying the number of lines to be shown.

You can omit the letter n and use just the hyphen (-) and the number (with no space between them).

Example:

head -n 30 filename.txt

or

head -30 filename.txt

Both will print the first 30 lines from the file filename.txt.

docs.title: Display a Specific Number of Bytes
docs.text:
The -c (--bytes) option allows to print a specific number of bytes.

head -c <NUMBER> filename.txt

Example:

head -c 100 filename.txt

This would print the first 100 bytes from the file filename.txt

You can also use a multiplier suffix after the number to specify the number of bytes to be shown. - b multiplies it by 512 - kB multiplies it by 1000 - K multiplies it by 1024 - MB multiplies it by 1000000 - M multiplies it by 1048576, and so on.

Example using multiplier:

head -c 5k filename.txt

This would read 5 KiloByte ( 5 x 1024 = 5120 ) bytes from the file filename.txt.

docs.title: Generating Random output FILE
docs.text:
head -c 1M /dev/urandom > sample.bin

This is very useful way generate custom random block of Data. It would write 1 MegaByte (1048576) of random data into sample.bin

docs.title: Displaying Multiple files
docs.text:
If multiple files are provided as input to the head command, it will display the first 10 lines from each provided file.

head filename1.txt filename2.txt

This example prints first 2 lines of each specified file:

head -n 2 filename1.txt filename2.txt

This can be especially useful in looking into code.

docs.title: Combining other commands with head
docs.text:
The head command can be used in combination with other commands by redirecting the standard output from/to other utilities using pipes.

The following command will hash the $RANDOM environment variable , display the first 32 bytes and display 24 characters random string:

echo $RANDOM | sha512sum | head -c 24 ; echo

docs.title: jq json processor command
docs.text:
Lightweight and flexible command-line JSON processor

Sources - https://github.com/stedolan/jq

Documentation - https://stedolan.github.io/jq/

Online JSON jq testing and Play Area - https://jqplay.org/

jq is like sed for JSON data - you can use it to slice and filter and map and transform structured data with the same ease that sed, awk, grep and friends let you play with text.

jq is written in portable C, and it has zero run-time dependencies. You can download a single binary, scp it to a far away machine of the same type, and expect it to work.

jq can mangle the data format that you have into the one that you want with very little effort, and the program to do so is often shorter and simpler than you'd expect.

Install: 

sudo pacman -S jq

docs.text:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/68859957/transform-a-list-of-strings-to-json-array-using-jq

cat list.txt | jq -Rn '[inputs]'

# Eliminate any empty Lines
cat list.txt | jq -Rn '[inputs|select(length>0)]'

# Work on Coma Separated Strings
cat list.txt | jq -R 'split(",")'

docs.title: Transform a JSON Array back to a List using jq and sed
docs.text:
jq .[] userwords.json | sed 's/"//g'

This would first print the JSON array in the file userwords.json. Then using sed remove the quotes.

docs.title: lsblk Command
docs.text:
lsblk lists information about all available or the specified block devices. This can be used to identify the storage devices connected on the system of various types. Be it a FUSE partition, LUKS volume or a standard NTFS, the lsblk command lets you see it all. It also helps to find mount points for the currently mounted storage. Note: This command requires sudo permissions.

There are multiple ways of using the lsblk command. These are defined by the options used while executing the command.

This would display all normal volumes and non-empty partitions.

Show System Topology - All RAM PCI CPU Hardware !!!

Sometimes we need to know what is our system configuration like (CPU, RAM, network interfaces, etc...), but we don't want to open computer case to look what's inside or even don't have such possibility, especially when we are connected to remote server.

docs.title: Lynx - Text-based Web Browser
docs.text:
Lynx is a highly configurable text-based web browser for use on cursor-addressable character cell terminals. It is ideal for use in terminal environments and over slow or remote connections like SSH. It supports browsing the web without requiring a graphical interface, making it lightweight and efficient.

Home Page: https://lynx.browser.org/

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Text-only browsing for fast and efficient navigation
  • Support for HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and local file browsing
  • Cookie support
  • Forms and authentication
  • Configurable keybindings and user-agent strings
  • Optional SSL certificate verification
  • Supports bookmarks and history navigation

docs.text:
https://popzazzle.blogspot.com/2022/06/lynx-browser-land-that-time-revived.html

  • / : Search for text in the page

docs.text:

  • lynx -source https://example.com : Print raw HTML source of the page

  • lynx -nolist : Disable the list of links at the end of dump
  • lynx -accept_all_cookies : Automatically accept all cookies

docs.title: 1. Browse Websites from the Terminal
docs.text:

Great for reading tech news or forums in SSH sessions.

docs.title: 2. Scripted Website Dumps

docs.title: make Build command
docs.text: GNU Make tool and its build language.

docs.title: Formatting
docs.text:
IMPORTANT

Makefile uses TAB as the separator for alignment under targets not space.

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
• To use the defined variables in Makefile use expansion ${VARIABLE}
  • To use environment variables in Makefile use expansion $$ENV_VAR or $${ENV_VAR}
    • eg. echo $$PWD This would print the present directory

docs.title: Targets
docs.text:
• To specify targets in the Makefile one must use the .PHONY target to specify them.
    • eg. .PHONY: test, build, all This Makefile contains the targets = test, build, all
    • We need to specify the .PHONY either at the end of the Makefile or just before the target declaration starts.

docs.title: Getting Executable code in Makefile or use BASH commands
docs.text:
Makefile are one of the basic things used for building software using GNU #make.

In order to be able to execute code in MAC there are 2 ways.

  1. Box commands in shell expansion
  2. Include BASH as a shell

docs.title: Include BASH as a shell in Make
docs.text:
Add the following line at the beginning of the file:

SHELL=/bin/bash

This would enable the BASH shell for all the make targets.

docs.title: Using shell expansion
docs.text:
The typical shell expansion gets stored in a Variable: 

OUTPUT=$(shell <command>)

docs.title: Find the Current Directory Name in Makefile using shell
docs.text:
DIR=$(shell cd . && echo $${PWD##*/})

This finds the current directory name that the make is executing in.

docs.title: Find directory name relative to Current Directory if it exists in Makefile
docs.text:
Now this one is complex.

  • It first finds out if the directory does exists.
  • If it exists then it assigns the variable else it keeps the variable Blank
DIR=$(shell cd cmd/AW516X && echo $${PWD##*/})

docs.title: Get Version from a Source file using Makefile
docs.text:
This might be a useful trick. We would try to get the version from a comment in the source code. Typically a version or semver looks like this: v1.2.3

We would this pattern to be matched. Though there might be more expansive things let's keep it simple for this explanation.

Here is how the main.go source file content looks like:

...
// Version "v1.0.1"
...

We would like to extract this.

Lets first try a grep on the main.go file:

$ grep -E "v[0-9].[0-9].[0-9]" main.go
// Version "v1.0.1"

So we have a correct regular expression to be used. Let's now use awk to actually pull the data out.

$ awk '/"v[0-9].[0-9].[0-9]"/ {split($3, a, "\"");print a[2]}' main.go
v1.0.1

We use the split on the last token in the search operation. This would break the version string into 3 parts divided by the " separator. Finally we print the middle unit of the resultant array from split.

Note

All things in awk have starting index of 1.

Finally lets re-write it in Makefile: 

VERSION=$(shell awk '/"v[0-9].[0-9].[0-9]"/ {split($$3,a,"\"");print a[2]}' main.go)

Note: We added a extra $ in the awk to escape it in Makefile.

docs.title: Makefile with all above experiments
docs.text:
Here is how the makefile would look like:

DIR=$(shell cd . && echo $${PWD##*/})

.PHONY: test, build, format, clean, all, run

VERSION=$(shell awk '/"v[0-9].[0-9].[0-9]"/ {split($$3,a,"\"");print a[2]}' main.go)

build:
    echo "${DIR} $$PWD"
    echo "${VERSION}"

# Escape the passed Arguments
%:
    @:

docs.title: Argument Processing
docs.text:
Getting arguments specified with Makefile in command line:

args = $(filter-out $@,$(MAKECMDGOALS))

All the arguments are now stored in the args variable.

Note: make treats all arguments supplied as target. In order to escape it add this at the bottom of the Makefile: makefile > # Escape the passed Arguments > %: > @: >

docs.title: Conditional Execution in Makefile
docs.text:
https://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Conditional-Syntax.html

Yes make can have conditional execution. It is kind of essential to react to various stimuli and provide a programmable path for executing the build.

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
IMPORTANT

Conditional directives always start from the beginning of the line. They are never indented with tab.

...
conditional-directive  # this is right
...
    conditional-directive # this is WRONG
...

Extra spaces are allowed and ignored at the beginning of the conditional directive line, but a tab is not allowed. (If the line begins with a tab, it will be considered part of a recipe for a rule or target.)

Aside from this, extra spaces or tabs may be inserted with no effect anywhere except within the directive name or within an argument. A comment starting with # may appear at the end of the line.

For more Information:

https://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Conditional-Syntax.html

docs.title: 1. Single Conditional directives
docs.text:
conditional-directive
    text-if-true
endif
The text-if-true may be any lines of text, to be considered as part of the Makefile if the condition is true. If the condition is false, no text is used instead.

docs.title: 2. Complex Conditional directives with one level
docs.text:
conditional-directive
    text-if-true
else
    text-if-false
endif
Once a given condition is true, text-if-true is used and no other clause is used; else text-if-false is used. The text-if-true and text-if-false can be any number of lines of text.

docs.title: 3. Multi-level or ladder Conditional directives
docs.text:
conditional-directive-one
    text-if-one-is-true
else conditional-directive-two
    text-if-two-is-true
...
else
    text-if-all-are-false
endif

There can be as many else conditional-directive clauses as necessary. Once a given condition is true, text-if-true of that conditional-directive is used and no other clause is used. If no condition in the ladder is true then text-if-all-are-false is used.

The text-if-true and text-if-false can be any number of lines of text.

The syntax of the conditional-directive is the same whether the conditional is simple or complex; after an else or not.

docs.title: 1.  Equality
docs.text:
ifeq (arg1, arg2).

ifeq 'arg1' 'arg2'

ifeq "arg1" "arg2"

ifeq "arg1" 'arg2'

ifeq 'arg1' "arg2"

Expand all variable references in arg1 and arg2 and compare them. If they are identical, the text-if-true is effective; otherwise, the text-if-false, if any, is effective.

docs.title: 2.  Non-Equality
docs.text:
ifneq (arg1, arg2)

ifneq 'arg1' 'arg2'

ifneq "arg1" "arg2"

ifneq "arg1" 'arg2'

ifneq 'arg1' "arg2"

Expand all variable references in arg1 and arg2 and compare them. If they are different, the text-if-true is effective; otherwise, the text-if-false, if any, is effective.

docs.title: 3.  Defined
docs.text:
ifdef variable-name

The ifdef form takes the name of a variable as its argument, not a reference to a variable. If the value of that variable has a non-empty value, the text-if-true is effective; otherwise, the text-if-false, if any, is effective. Variables that have never been defined have an empty value. The text variable-name is expanded, so it could be a variable or function that expands to the name of a variable.

docs.title: 4.  Not Defined
docs.text:
ifndef variable-name

If the variable variable-name has an empty value, the text-if-true is effective; otherwise, the text-if-false, if any, is effective. The rules for expansion and testing of variable-name are identical to the ifdef directive.

docs.title: 1. Check if a variable has a non empty value
docs.text:
ifeq ($(strip $(foo)),)
    text-if-empty
endif

Here we check if the expansion of $(foo) is empty or contains white-space.

docs.title: 2.  Check existence by reference
docs.text:
bar = true
foo = bar
ifdef $(foo)
frobozz = yes
endif

The variable reference $(foo) is expanded, yielding bar, which is considered to be the name of a variable. The variable bar is not expanded, but its value is examined to determine if it is non-empty.

Note

ifdef only tests whether a variable has a value. It does not expand the variable to see if that value is non-empty.

Consequently, tests using ifdef return true for all definitions except those like foo. To test for an empty value, use ifeq ($(foo),).

docs.title: 3. Optional Execution in a Recipe or target
docs.text:
OLDNAME=$(shell test -e go.mod && awk -F "/" '/module\s.*/ {print $$NF}' go.mod)

all:
ifeq "${OLDNAME}" ""
    echo "No file"
else
    echo "${OLDNAME}"
endif

Here are the important operations in the above code:-

  • Here if the go.mod exist then the OLDNAME variable gets allocated. Else its a empty value.
  • Evaluation shows the processing of OLDNAME or an Error message.

This is how a conditional execution can be included even as =target=s or recipe.

docs.title: mkcert Tool - Secure Localhost
docs.text:
mkcert is a simple tool for making locally-trusted development certificates. It requires no configuration.

https://github.com/FiloSottile/mkcert

Using certificates from real certificate authorities (CAs) for development can be dangerous or impossible (for hosts like example.test, localhost or 127.0.0.1), but self-signed certificates cause trust errors. Managing your own CA is the best solution, but usually involves arcane commands, specialized knowledge and manual steps.

mkcert automatically creates and installs a local CA in the system root store, and generates locally-trusted certificates. mkcert does not automatically configure servers to use the certificates, though, that's up to you.

$ mkcert -install
Created a new local CA 💥
The local CA is now installed in the system trust store! ⚡️
The local CA is now installed in the Firefox trust store (requires browser restart)! 🦊

$ mkcert example.com "*.example.com" example.test localhost 127.0.0.1 ::1

Created a new certificate valid for the following names 📜
 - "example.com"
 - "*.example.com"
 - "example.test"
 - "localhost"
 - "127.0.0.1"
 - "::1"

The certificate is at "./example.com+5.pem" and the key at "./example.com+5-key.pem" ✅

docs.title: Installing
docs.text: sudo pacman -S mkcert

docs.title: Miller (mlr)
docs.text:
Miller (https://miller.readthedocs.io/) is a powerful command-line tool for handling structured data formats like CSV, TSV, JSON, and others. It acts like a "sed, awk, cut, join, and sort" for data files and is exceptionally useful for data analysis, filtering, and transformation on the command line.

Sources https://github.com/johnkerl/miller

docs.title: On Windows
docs.text: You can install Miller on Windows in the following ways:

docs.title: Using Chocolatey
docs.text: choco install miller

docs.title: Using Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)
docs.text:
1. Install WSL and set up a Linux distribution (e.g., Ubuntu).
  2. Open the WSL terminal and follow the Linux instructions:
sudo apt update && sudo apt install miller

docs.title: Using Precompiled Binaries
docs.text:
1. Go to the Releases page on GitHub.
  2. Download the appropriate Windows zip file.
  3. Unzip it and add the mlr.exe location to your PATH environment variable.

docs.title: On Debian/Ubuntu
docs.text: sudo apt install miller

docs.title: On macOS (Homebrew)
docs.text: brew install miller

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/johnkerl/miller.git
cd miller
make && sudo make install

docs.title: 📂 Supported Formats in Miller
docs.text:
• CSV: Comma-separated values
  • TSV: Tab-separated values
  • JSON: Both JSON Lines (--json) and regular nested JSON (--json with --jvstack)
  • DKVP: Delimiter-keyed value pairs (e.g., name=John,age=30)
  • NIDX: Implicit index-based format

docs.title: CSV to JSON
docs.text: mlr --icsv --ojson cat data.csv

docs.title: JSON to CSV
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ocsv cat data.json

docs.title: TSV to CSV
docs.text: mlr --itsv --ocsv cat data.tsv

docs.title: DKVP to CSV
docs.text: echo 'name=John,age=28' | mlr --idkvp --ocsv cat

docs.title: Selecting Specific Fields (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv cut -f name,age data.csv

docs.title: Selecting Specific Fields (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson cut -f name,age data.json

docs.title: Removing Specific Fields (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv cut -x -f id data.csv

docs.title: Removing Specific Fields (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson cut -x -f debug_info data.json

docs.title: Filtering Rows (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv filter '$age > 30' data.csv

docs.title: Filtering Rows (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson filter '$active == true && $role == "admin"' data.json

docs.title: Complex Filtering with Regex (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv filter '$name =~ "^A" && $age > 25' data.csv

docs.title: Filtering on Nested JSON Fields in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson put '$city = $address.city' then filter '$city == "Mumbai"' data.json

docs.title: Filtering Using Field Existence in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson filter 'is_present($email)' data.json

docs.title: Add or Modify Columns (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv put '$full_name = $first_name . " " . $last_name' data.csv

docs.title: Add or Modify Fields (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson put '$full_name = $first_name . " " . $last_name' data.json

docs.title: Remove Duplicates (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv uniq -a data.csv

docs.title: Sort by Field (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv sort -f age data.csv

docs.title: Sort by Field (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson sort -f timestamp data.json

docs.title: Group-by Aggregation (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv stats1 -a mean,sum -f salary -g department data.csv

docs.title: Group-by Aggregation (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson stats1 -a count,mean -f rating -g category data.json

docs.title: Rename Fields (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv rename fname,first_name,lname,last_name data.csv

docs.title: Rename Fields (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson rename fname,first_name,lname,last_name data.json

docs.title: Replace Field Values in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv put '$status = "complete" if $status == "done" else $status' data.csv

docs.title: Replace Text Globally in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv put '$comment = sub($comment, "old", "new")' data.csv

docs.title: Replace in JSON Field in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson put '$note = sub($note, "foo", "bar")' data.json

docs.title: Exploding JSON Arrays into Rows in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson --jvstack cat data.json

docs.title: Reformat Column Names in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv label id,name,age,city data.csv

docs.title: Counting Rows (CSV) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --csv count data.csv

docs.title: Counting Rows (JSON) in Miller
docs.text: mlr --ijson --ojson count data.json

docs.title: CSV ETL in Miller
docs.text:
mlr --icsv --ojson \
  filter '$age > 25' \
  then put '$full_name = $first . " " . $last' \
  then cut -f full_name,age,city \
  data.csv

docs.title: JSON ETL in Miller
docs.text:
mlr --ijson --ojson \
  put '$full_address = $address.street . ", " . $address.city' \
  then cut -f name,email,full_address \
  then filter '$email =~ "@example.com"' \
  data.json

docs.title: 📝 Notes on Miller
docs.text:
• Use --ifs, --ofs to specify input/output field separators
  • --repifs and --reofs can help clean malformed files

docs.title: Example:
docs.text: mlr --icsv --otsv --ifs ',' --ofs '\t' cat data.csv > data.tsv

docs.title: 🏁 Summary
docs.text:
Miller is a must-have utility in the data engineer's toolkit. With its blazing speed and expressive DSL, it handles gigabyte-scale files with ease. Whether you're cleaning logs, transforming CSVs, or reshaping JSON, Miller is your Swiss Army knife.

Explore more with mlr --help and chain commands with pipes | to create powerful ETL flows.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• nix Combo Command

    • repl for direct nix REPL command-line. :? for help and :q to Quit.
    • show-derivation details a supplied derivation path in good format
      • Needs --experimental-features nix-command in the newer version of Nix.

  • nix-store = Nix Store management

    • Find Refs in particular package = -q --references <path>
    • Find which other packages refers to this package = -q --referrers <path>
    • Display all package dependencies recursively in a tree form = -q --tree <Path>
    • Do Cleanup or Garbage Collect = --gc

  • nix-build = Actually

    • -A is used to access a particular attribute in the supplied main file like:

      nix-build default.nix -A hello

  • nix-collect-garbage = Cleanup nix store Command for un-used references

  • Remove all previous generations -d or --delete-old

  • Dryrun the cleanup --dry-run

  • nix-instantiate = instantiate store derivations from Nix expressions

  • --eval To show the output but do not build

  • Automatically used in nix-build

  • nix-prefetch-url = Command to download file to Nix Store and show the resulting Nix file compatible SHA256 Hash.

  • --print-path option shows the Nix Store path where the resource was downloaded.

  • --extract option extracts the archive downloaded and shows the combined hash.

  • nixos-rebuild Command to work on NixOS installation

    • build = Just performs the Build and not switch

      • It internally does a nix-build of a given system module
      • nix-build '<nixpkgs/nixos>' -A system
      • This builds the derivation that explains the whole system.

    • test = Only generate a temporary build to test if everything is working

    • build-vm = Create a VM of current Configuration. It can open a

    • switch = Build and Switch

      • It does the build command as above.
      • The it links the derivation to /nix/var/nix/profiles/system
      • And finally it shifts the /run/current-system to this new link. By running the script <drv>/bin/switch-to-configuration switch.

  • DO NOT USE nix-env and nix-channels They are Deprecated

  • nix-env = Current Environment Manipulation and Generation

    • Install -i
    • list -q
    • Get Generations --list-generations
    • Move to A generation -G <GenNumber>
    • Roll-back the Last generation --rollback
    • Remove a particular package -e <packag-name>
    • Remove all Packages -e '*'
    • Remove all Packages in single transaction - --remove-all or -r
    • Upgrade all in the current environment -u
    • Upgrade all packages in all generations for current profile --always

  • nix-channel = Nix Source Channel management tool

    • Add --add <URI> <Name>
    • Update --update
    • Get Generations --list-generations

Nmap is a powerful network scanning tool for security audits and penetration testing. It is one of the essential tools used by network administrators to troubleshooting network connectivity issues and port scanning .

docs.title: GUI for nmap the zenmap Not for Debian

https://nmap.org/zenmap/

Zenmap is the official Nmap Security Scanner GUI. It is a multi-platform (Linux, Windows, Mac OS X, BSD, etc.) free and open source application which aims to make Nmap easy for beginners to use while providing advanced features for experienced Nmap users. Frequently used scans can be saved as profiles to make them easy to run repeatedly. A command creator allows interactive creation of Nmap command lines. Scan results can be saved and viewed later. Saved scan results can be compared with one another to see how they differ. The results of recent scans are stored in a searchable database.

You can download Zenmap (often packaged with Nmap itself) from the Nmap download page. Zenmap is quite intuitive, but you can learn more about using it from the Zenmap User's Guide or check out the Zenmap man page for some quick reference information.

docs.title: The Multi-platform Security command that Works!
Generate Random Data from OpenSSL using Encryption
docs.text:
head -c 100m /dev/zero |\
    openssl enc -aes-128-cbc \
        -pass pass:"$(head -c 20 /dev/urandom | base64)"  > my100MBfile

This command does the following steps:

  1. Generate the 100MB of Zero Byte Data
  2. Generate a Password of 20 characters using /dev/urandom process it using base64
  3. Encrypt the data using AES-128-CBC to generate the file
  4. Store data into my100MBfile

The amount generated data can be varied using the head command. The 100m indicates 100 Mega in Bytes of Data. It can be 5m for only 5MiB of data.

Note: The end result is a binary output.

It can easily be converted to text if needed using: 

head -c 100m /dev/zero |\
    openssl enc -aes-128-cbc \
        -pass pass:"$(head -c 20 /dev/urandom | base64)" |\
    base64 > my100MBfile.txt

The last base64 would convert it to a text data.

docs.title: Encrypt a File
docs.text:
openssl enc -e -aes-256-cbc -k passphrase -a -in  TestingFile.txt -out Enc.txt

Here the -e used for encryption.

Note

-a option is used for BASE64 encoding.

Note

passphrase is the password used to perform the encryption.

If we want to print the IV Key and other Details add the -p option

openssl enc -e -aes-256-cbc -k passphrase -a -p -in  TestingFile.txt -out Enc.txt

If we want to allow the user the enter the Password we ca use the command like this:

openssl enc -e -aes-256-cbc -a -p -pbkdf2 -in TestingFile.txt -out Enc.txt

Note

This also works in Windows on MSYS2.

docs.title: Decrypt the File
docs.text:
openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -k passphrase -a -in Enc.txt -out Dec.txt

Here the -d used for decryption.

Again for accepting the user Password in command line:

openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -a -pbkdf2 -in Enc.txt -out Dec.txt

Note

This also works in Windows on MSYS2.

docs.title: Encrypt/Decrypt files for transfer.sh
docs.text:
# Encrypt files with password using openssl
$ cat /tmp/hello.txt|openssl aes-256-cbc -pbkdf2 -e| \
    curl -X PUT --upload-file "-" https://transfer.sh/test.txt

There are 3 parts in this command:

  1. Send the file contents to openssl
  2. Use openssl to encrypt using aes-256-cbc with -pbkdf2 Key derivation function and -e to ask for password from user to Encrypt.
  3. Finally upload the file to transfer.sh service.

The reverse is also easy:

# Download and decrypt
$ curl https://transfer.sh/bqsnEP9ik8/test.txt| \
    openssl aes-256-cbc -pbkdf2 -d > /tmp/hello.txt

Here we are using curl command output to openssl and -d with decrypt by asking user password again.

Note

This also works in Windows on MSYS2.

docs.title: paperkey OpenPGP key to Paper
docs.text:
GPG Paper Backup Tool.

Home Page: https://www.jabberwocky.com/software/paperkey/

A reasonable way to achieve a long term backup of OpenPGP (GnuPG, PGP, etc) keys is to print them out on paper. Paper and ink have amazingly long retention qualities - far longer than the magnetic or optical means that are generally used to back up computer data.

Repository: https://github.com/dmshaw/paperkey/

docs.title: Install
docs.text: sudo pacman -S paperkey

docs.title: Creating paperkey for GPG Private Key
docs.text:
paperkey --secret-key private-master-key --output private-paper-key.txt

Here private-master-key is the binary export of the GPG Key. This would generate the private-paper-key.txt that can be printed. Printing can also be done using Large QR-Code or in OCR Fonts. That would help to read back the paper key.

docs.title: Restoring GPG Private Key from paperkey
docs.text:
paperkey --pubring public.key --secrets paper-key.txt --output private-key

Here public.key is a Binary export of GPG Key that we are trying to recover. The paper-key.txt is the scanned form of the paperkey printed earlier. Finally private-key will be the binary GPG Private Key that can be imported.

docs.title: 🔧 What is qrencode?
docs.text: qrencode is a command-line utility that encodes text into QR codes and outputs them as image files. It supports various output formats like PNG, ANSI text, and SVG.

docs.title: Ubuntu/Debian : qrencode
docs.text: sudo apt install qrencode

docs.title: Fedora : qrencode
docs.text: sudo dnf install qrencode

docs.title: macOS (via Homebrew) : qrencode
docs.text: brew install qrencode

docs.title: Windows : qrencode options
docs.text: On Windows, there is no official qrencode binary, but you have several alternatives:

docs.title: Option 1: Use Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)
docs.text:
1. Install WSL and set up Ubuntu.
  2. Launch WSL and install qrencode:
sudo apt update && sudo apt install qrencode

docs.title: Option 2: Use a Precompiled Binary (Unofficial)
docs.text:
• You may find Windows builds of qrencode on repositories like https://github.com/fukuchi/libqrencode or third-party sources.
  • Note: Use binaries from trusted sources and verify checksums.

docs.title: Option 3: Use Python with qrcode library
docs.text: • Install Python and use the qrcode module to generate Wi-Fi QR codes (see alternative script-based approach).

docs.title: Wi-Fi QR Code Format
docs.text:
Wi-Fi QR codes follow a specific string format:

WIFI:T:<encryption>;S:<ssid>;P:<password>;H:<hidden>;;
Field Description T Encryption type: WPA, WEP, or empty for open networks S SSID (Wi-Fi network name) P Password H (Optional) true if the SSID is hidden

docs.title: WPA/WPA2/WPA3
docs.text: qrencode -o wifi_wpa.png "WIFI:T:WPA;S:MyNetwork;P:MySecretPass;;"

docs.title: WEP
docs.text: qrencode -o wifi_wep.png "WIFI:T:WEP;S:MyWEPNet;P:WEPpass123;;"

docs.title: Open Network (No Password)
docs.text: qrencode -o wifi_open.png "WIFI:T:;S:OpenNet;;"

docs.title: Hidden SSID
docs.text: qrencode -o wifi_hidden.png "WIFI:T:WPA;S:HiddenSSID;P:secret;H:true;;"

docs.title: Useful Options for qrencode
docs.text:
Option Description -o <file> Output filename (e.g., wifi.png) -s <size> Pixel size of each module (default: 3) -l <L|M|Q|H> Error correction level from L (lowest) to H (highest). (default=L) -m <margin> Margin size around the QR code (default: 4) -t <type> Output format: PNG, ANSI, SVG, etc.

For mode detailed option use qrencode -h or man qrencode to learn more.

docs.title: Example with Custom Size and Error Correction
docs.text: qrencode -o wifi_custom.png -s 10 -l H "WIFI:T:WPA;S:MySSID;P:MyPass;;"

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The double semicolon ;; at the end is mandatory.
  • If your SSID or password contains special characters (like ;, \, or ,), they should be escaped or encoded.

# Command Format
rsync -{options} source destination

Here are the Parts: - -{options} There can be multiple options here based on what and where we care copying or synchronizing data. All options can be clubbed together to form a single String. - soruce This is the absolute path to the source directory. - destination This the one level above the destination directory that needs to be synced. This is an important caveat. We can also specify the absolute path but need to follow correct grammar.

docs.title: Examples detailing the Use
docs.text:
Here are Few Example that Explain this:

## 1. Backup all the Log Files to a Storage
# Destination Directory = /mnt/backup/log
# (Storage Device mounted at /mnt )
# Soruce Directory = /var/log
sudo rsync -av /var/log /mnt/backup
# Note the destination 'log' Got created automatically
# Here the options:
# -v option = Verbose - Full output
# -a option = Archive Mode
#            - Copy all Subdirectories
#            - Retain the Permissions
#            - Matches Source and Destination and Meta Data

## 2. Simulating a Copy
sudo rsync -av --dry-run /var/log /mnt/backup
# --dry-run = Its simulation to show what would happen

## 3. Copy Data from one Linux machine to Another
# Note Make sure ~rsync~ is install on Both Servers
# Source Directory = /var/log
# Destination = myuser@139.159.1.250:/mnt/backup
#   Here we are connecting as `myuser` to machine IP
#   139.159.1.250 and Directory /mnt/backup
sudo rsync -av /var/log \
  myuser@139.159.1.250:/mnt/backup
# This would use an 'SSH' connection under the hood
# to copy the files to the remote Linux machine.

## 4. Remote Copy - Absolute Path Grammar !!!
sudo rsync --dry-run -avz /mnt/nexcloud-data/ \
  myuser@192.134.22.12:/mnt/backup-data/nextcloud/
# Note the Slashes at the End of the Source and Destination
#  These help to create Absolute Path reference and
#  is called *Absolution Path Grammer !!!*
#  This makes ure that the conent of the folder
#  is copied not the folder itself.
# -z option = Helps you to compress while sending
#     data to the other side.

## 5. For a Special Long time taking copy
sudo rsync --dry-run --progress -avz \
  /mnt/nexcloud-data/ \
  myuser@192.134.22.12:/mnt/backup-data/nextcloud/
# --progress option = helps to show a progress bar
#      for long running process.

## 6. Single File Copy
rsync myfiles/photos.zip subscribe
# Note that we dont need to specify name or / for the
#   destination folder.

## 7. Simple Recursive Copy
rsync -r myfiles/ subscribe/
# Note the '/' at the end of the Source and Destination
# This is the Absolute Path Grammar !!!
# Note this would not Preserve the Meta Data
# Hence it is recommend to use -a the Archive mode option
rsync -a myfiles/ subscribe/

## 8. Best Options to Sync Data
rsync -ac myfile/ subscribe/
# -c option = Would force Rsync to overwrite or skip
#    coping if the Destination file Checksum ==
#    matches Soruce file Checksum then Skip.

## 9. Make the Data a bit more readable
rsync -ach --progress myfile/ subscribe/
# -h option = This allows to make the data shown in human readable form
#   like MB or GB instead of bytes.
# --progress = This would show the Data-rate and copy times .etc.

## 10. Copying Big files over un-reliable connections
#    Speically bad USB cables and hanging drives
rsync -ach --progress --prartial \
   myfile/ subscribe/
# --partial = copyies in partial chunks so if the copy
#     process gets interrupted by some network or power issue
#     the partial copied file would remain. And the command
#     would resume copy from the parts after the exisiting,
#     reducing the time to copy the files.
rsync -achP myfile/ subscribe/
# -P option = Combines the --progress --prartial together.

## 11. Identical Synchronization of Directories
#     Means that all files from source would be same as in the destinaiton.
#     In case the Destination has a few files extra they would
#     automatically be deleted.
rsync -achP --delete myfile/ subscribe/
# --delete = This would remove any files on the Destiation location
#    if they don't exist in the source location.
#   This is helpful in keeping 2 folders in absolute sync.
#   Very good for .git kind of folders.

## 12. Copy files and Delete the Source
rsync -achP --remove-source-files myfile/ subscribe/ &&\
  find myfile -type d -empty -delete
# --remove-source-files = Removes the Soruce files recursively
#    But it leaves the empty directories.
# Hence the find command removes them too.

## 13. Copy from Remote Server to Local
rsync -achPz root@20.232.22.3:/root/subscribe/ myfile/
# -z option = Added here to support compression while transporting file
# Note that on the Remote you need to have the rsync installed.

## 14. SSH Options in Rsysnc
rsync -achPz -e 'ssh -p 2212 -i ~/.ssh/id_other ' \
  root@20.232.22.3:/root/subscribe/ myfile/
# -e option = This lets us specify the SSH options using
#   a format of SSH command.
# Here the SSH commad uses the followitng variation:
# -p option = Custom port used for SSH
# -i option = Custom Identity file used for connecting
#    to the server.

## 15. Better File Diffrences before Move
rsync -achPi --delete --dry-run myfile/ subscribe/
# -i option = This shows a specific Itemized list of Changes
#   that would be made to the Destination.

docs.title: Local SSH Tunnel in Detail or Forward Tunnel
docs.text:
Original Source file from Excalidraw

ssh -i .ssh/remote-key -L 127.0.0.1:8000:localhost:4000 root@220.128.122.123

The Local Tunnel helps to connect with the server via port 22 in SSH and expose a service hosted inside the remote server. This internal service on the remote server is available on port 4000 locally only, not exposed to the internet. This Local Tunnel maps the remote servers internal service on 4000 to the workstations local port 8000. Hence the service can now be access via http://localhost:8000 for a sample HTTP service.

How the Tunnel is specified:

-L localIP:localPort:remoteIP:remotePort

Here is a break down of each part:

  • localIP This is the local workstation internal IP like 127.0.0.1 or localhost. This can be optional.
  • localPort This must be specified and unique. Meaning that no other service should be accessing/listening on this. This is where the remote service would get mapped to.
  • remoteIP This is the Remote Server's internal IP. This can also be IP of a PC that is accessible on the local network on the Remote Server.
  • remotePort This is the port of a service on either the Remote Server or a PC on its local network.

Info

Note The local workstation should have a SSH Key pair to access the Remote Server and Remote server must have the public key of that key pair registered as an Authorized Key in its SSH.

docs.title: Remote SSH Tunnel in Detail or Reverse Tunnel
docs.text:
Here there are two cases need to be looked at : 1. Internal: Someone Reaching In from the Remote Server towards the Local workstation 2. External: Someone from any where as Reaching in through the Gateway port on the Remote Server. Also Remote Server in this case is often called called as SSH Jump Server.

Info

Note The second case requires more modifications on the Remote server's Side to allow external entities over internet to access the Local Workstation over SSH.

Let us first look at the case of internal remote tunnel(Not exposed over the internet).

docs.title: Remote SSH Tunnel Internal
docs.text:
Original Source From Excalidraw

Here is the command given the Local Workstation:

ssh -i .ssh/remote-key -R 127.0.0.1:2200:localhost:22 root@220.128.122.123

Info

Note The Local Workstation has the SSH Key pair installed to connect to the Remote Server.

Here we are exposing localhost:22 port on the Local Workstation to the Remote Server internal port port 127.0.0.1:2200. This command will open an SSH session into the Remote Server. However now any one else connected to the Remote server can access the Local Workstation's SSH using this. Let's looks at how that looks like.

Here is the command given on the Remote Server:

ssh -i .ssh/workstation-key -p 2200 user1@localhost

Info

Note The Remote Server has the SSH Key pair installed to connect to the Local Workstation else, it can connect using a password.

Here the Remote server uses the Key for the Local Workstation to access its SSH port mapped to 2200 earlier. This is the Reverse Tunnel part.

Now this is still an internal tunnel. And we also need to maintain keys on the Remote server. One for connecting to it which is a Public Key so it should not be a problem. However we also maintain a set of keys for the Local Workstation, which might not always be a safe thing to do. But again that depends on the use-case requirements. Let us now look at another way to have this same connection.

docs.title: Remote SSH Tunnel Command
docs.text:
Though this looks very similar to the Local SSH Tunnel it works is completely different ways.

-R remoteIP:reportPort:localIP:localPort

Here are the parts: 1. remoteIP This is the Remote Server Machine / Jump Server IP Address. There is a reason its called the Jump Server which will become clear shortly. This can either be the localhost as in 127.0.0.1 which means that it would be only available locally on the Remote Server Machine or the All interface IP 0.0.0.0. The reason we might want to so that is to allow all the interfaces on the Remote Server Machine to get the access to the Tunnel. This All interface IP then allows the Remote Server to pass out through its own External connections towards the Internet. Hence any other machine on the Internet with access to the Public IP address of the Remote Server can Tunnel Back into the Local Workstation via the Remote Servers open external Interface, this is why the Remote Server then becomes the Jump Server. The external machines can use the Remote Server to Jump back / Connect to the Local Workstation without having direct access to it. Also remember that the Local Workstation is behind a firewall and no port on that firewall are exposed for external. Hence the name Reverse Tunnel. 2. reportPort This the Remote Server port that the Tunnel will open towards. 3. localIP This is typically the Local Workstation self IP 127.0.0.1 or localhost. However this can also be a local machine which the Local Workstation has access to. Meaning our Local Workstation can act as a Router to give access to a certain machine on the Local network over to the external world via the Reverse tunnel. 4. localPort This is port number of the application or service that we wish to expose. This need not be only the SSH service it can be any type of local service.

Warning

Note: Opening Reverse tunnel is always a security risk. Hence should not be handled carelessly. There should be authentication safeguards and robust security etc. in place to help migrate the threats. Also this type of tunneling can be used by a treat actor to gain access to various network resources or hijack the secure networks completely. Hence take extra care why doing Reverse Tunneling.

docs.text:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -a 100 -C "web-vm" -f ".ssh/web-vm-key"

Where -t ed25519 specifies the Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) algorithm called Curve25519 used for ECDH ( Elliptic-Curve Diffie-Hellman) in SSH.

For Further reading on ECDH curves and all related https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/50878/ecdsa-vs-ecdh-vs-ed25519-vs-curve25519.

The -a 100 specifies the number of trials to run before settling on the key value. This pushes more randomness into the Diffie-Hellman derivation scheme.

The -C "web-vm" is a helpful tag or comment that might help to identify the purpose and intended target of the key.

The -f ".ssh/web-vm-key" specifies the exact file where the key will be stored.

docs.title: Hostname Alias in SSH
docs.text:
Reference :

  • Configuration to add Alias for hosts

    https://friendo.monster/log/ssh_config.html

~/.ssh/config lets you make what we can call as ssh aliases. You can give connections short names and specify various connection settings ‒ pretty much anything you can pass to ssh's CLI can be configured here.

Here's a simple example:

Host nas
    Hostname 192.168.1.10

Host laptop
    Hostname 192.168.1.11
    User laptop-me

Host someserver
    Hostname 203.0.113.1
    User seriousthings
    Port 10100
    PubkeyAuthentication yes
    Identityfile ~/.ssh/id_rsa_seriousthings

Host *
    PubkeyAuthentication no

Then you are able to do, for example:

ssh nas

These settings apply from top to bottom, cumulatively. So you want to structure this file with specific rules above general rules, otherwise the general rules will override the specific, which is not what you want.

One nice benefit is that you'll get autocompletion of hosts defined in ~/.ssh/config when using ssh under bash or zsh (at least).

~/.ssh/config can also be used to shore up some of the leaky parts of sshing, as described at the link below ‒ the whole page, and other articles in the series (linked at the top) are worth a read if you use ssh a decent amount.

docs.title: Structure of SSH Client Config
docs.text:
This in the ~/.ssh/config file:

Host c1
    HostName 192.168.0.1

Host c2
    HostName 192.168.0.2

Host c*
    User cytopia
    Port 10022
    PubkeyAuthentication yes
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa__c_cytopia@cytopia-macbook

# For github usage
Host github.com
    HostName github.com
    User git
    PubkeyAuthentication yes
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_github

    PubkeyAuthentication no
    IdentitiesOnly yes
    HashKnownHosts yes
    ServerAliveInterval 30

docs.title: Aliases for the IP Addresses
docs.text:
A Section of the ~/.ssh/config file:

Host c1
    HostName 192.168.0.1

Host c2
    HostName 192.168.0.2
...

The first 2 sections are Alias defined. Now this means you use ssh like this:

ssh c1
ssh c2
...

Internally this becomes:

ssh cyptopia@192.168.0.1 -p 10022 \
    -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa__c_cytopia@cytopia-macbook \
    -o PubkeyAuthentication=yes \
    -o ServerAliveInterval=30
# Similar to
ssh c1

docs.title: Rules for Writing the ~/.ssh/config file
docs.text:
You can basically categorize ssh blocks into three stages:

  1. Most specific (without any wildcards)
  2. Some generalization (with wildcard definitions)
  3. General section (which applies to all).

So always remember:

  1. Specific definitions at the top
  2. General definitions at the bottom
  3. Whenever a specific value has been found, it cannot be overwritten by values defined below.

Note

Regarding the ~/.ssh/config it is important to keep track of is the Host section (aligned to the left). Notice here that the general definitions are at the very top and more wildcard definitions (using the asterisk *) are followed below.

If you want to ssh connect to c1 (ssh c1), the file is read as follows:

  1. Find section Host c1 and use its corresponding HostName (192.168.0.1)
  2. Find more general section Host c* and use their values (User, Port, etc).
  3. Find most general section Host *
    1. Don't use User as it has already been defined for this connection in c*
    2. Don't use Port as it has already been defined for this connection in c*
    3. Don't use PubkeyAuthentication as it has already been defined for this connection in c*
    4. Use ServerAliveInterval as there is no previous definition.

docs.title: Autocompletion in SSH Client
docs.text:
You will have autocompletion (at least under bash or zsh) for every host and every alias defined in ~/.ssh/config file. This is true for hosts and even IP addresses.

When you type ssh 1 and hit tab:

$ ssh 1
192.168.0.1     192.168.0.2     192.168.0.3     192.168.0.4

Note: We have replaced the IP addresses with internal once.

Here is another Example with alias:

$ ssh c
c1     c2

docs.title: To fix Identity leak problem via SSH keys
docs.text:
Add these to your ~/.ssh/config:

...
# Turn off pubkey auth for all hosts
Host *
    PubkeyAuthentication no
    IdentitiesOnly yes
    ServerAliveInterval 30
...

Warning

This would not allow you to login SSH Servers without public Keys installed.

It is Safer to have it as:

...
# Generic Config
Host *
    #PubkeyAuthentication no
    #IdentitiesOnly yes
    HashKnownHosts yes
    ServerAliveInterval 30
    UseRoaming no
...

docs.title: Protect known_host SSH against Harvesting Attack
docs.text:
...
# Generic Config
Host *
    ...
    HashKnownHosts yes
...

This would enable unique hash for the Host entries. Note: Make sure to remove the existing ~/.ssh/known_hosts file.

  1. Known Problems with HashKnownHosts yes setting

    Warning

    Some times when the Host configuration changes this would block the connection.

    If you get the message:

    @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
@    WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED!     @
@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOMEONE IS DOING SOMETHING NASTY!
Someone could be eavesdropping on you right now (man-in-the-middle attack)!
It is also possible that a host key has just been changed.
......
......

    In the above Example: Installing the public Key into a particular host that was earlier accessed using username password.

    Solution:

    • Delete the ~/.ssh/known_hosts file or
    • remove the particular host entry in the file.

    It would fix this problem.

docs.title: tftp - Server and Client = Trivial File Transfer Protocol
tftp - Server and Client = Trivial File Transfer Protocol
docs.text:
The Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) is a simple lockstep communication protocol for transmitting or receiving files in a client-server application. A primary use of TFTP is in the early stages of nodes booting on a local area network when the operating system or firmware images are stored on a file server.

Trivial File Transfer Protocol client

https://linux.die.net/man/1/tftp

References:

  • How to install TFTP setup.

    https://fabianlee.org/2016/09/18/openwrt-installing-a-tftp-server-on-ubuntu-for-openwrt-firmware-updates/

    PDF

  • Better Guide:

    https://reintech.io/blog/installing-configuring-tftp-server-debian-12

    PDF

  • Older Version:

    https://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/install-configure-tftp-server-ubuntu-debian-howto/

    PDF

docs.title: TFTP Server Installation on Ubuntu
docs.text:
sudo apt update && sudo apt install tftpd-hpa tftp-hpa

The tftp-hpa is the client and tftpd-hpa is the Server daemon.

This needs systemd to be in the system being used.

docs.title: Configure the tftpd server
docs.text:
sudo nano /etc/default/tftpd-hpa

Modify the Contents to:

TFTP_USERNAME="tftp"
TFTP_DIRECTORY="/var/lib/tftpboot"
TFTP_ADDRESS="0.0.0.0:69"
TFTP_OPTIONS="--secure"

Now we need to create the directory if it does not exist already

sudo mkdir -p /var/lib/tftpboot

To test lets create a temporary file:

echo "Hari Aum" | sudo tee /var/lib/tftpboot/swagat.txt

docs.title: (Optional) ufw Firewall settings to allow tftp
docs.text: sudo ufw allow 69/udp comment "UDP for tftp"

docs.title: Last Step
docs.text:
Finally restart the tftpd service:

sudo systemctl restart tftpd-hpa

docs.title: Testing out the tftp Operation
docs.text:
Next we can try to download out File using tftp

ip -c addr

This would display the actual WiFi or Ethernet address

Start the TFTP client process:

tftp <Your-IP-address>

This would not work for the localhost it needs the actual address of the PC.

Now to download the filed we created earlier.

tftp> get swagat.txt
tftp> quit

Display the File:

$ cat swagat.txt
Hari Aum

This TFTP server is enabled at boot and hence can be easily accessed over network for boot.

docs.title: unexpand - convert spaces to tabs
docs.text:
Reference: https://linux.die.net/man/1/unexpand

Convert blanks in each FILE to tabs, writing to standard output. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

-a, --all
    convert all blanks, instead of just initial blanks
--first-only
    convert only leading sequences of blanks (overrides -a)
-t, --tabs=N
    have tabs N characters apart instead of 8 (enables -a)
-t, --tabs=LIST
    use comma separated LIST of tab positions (enables -a)

This command as a reversal command expand.

docs.title: Typical Usage of unexpand command
docs.text:
unexpand -t 1 test.txt

This would convert all the blank spaces to 1 tab expansion.

unexpand test.txt > test2.txt

This would convert all the blank spaces to 8 tab expansion which is the default value and store the output in test2.txt.

Due to problems in printing websites with Firefox I found this tool. It would help print website into PDF with all links preserved.

wkhtmltopdf and wkhtmltoimage are open source (LGPLv3) command line tools to render HTML into PDF and various image formats using the Qt WebKit rendering engine. These run entirely "headless" and do not require a display or display service.

  3. Run your HTML document through the tool. For example, if I really like the treatment Google has done to their logo today and want to capture it forever as a PDF: wkhtmltopdf http://google.com google.pdf

docs.title: Windows Folder Permission Fix for NTFS
docs.text:
We use the icacls Command.

  • Microsoft Forums: https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/how-to-write-a-batch-file-to-change-folder/3d1a937a-ee98-452c-abde-9d8ea6e2a56e

Its very common to get issues when the NTFS and other file systems gets mixed up. There arises problems with rights. Since some files get modified on another PC and some on Another. Hence the rights for files in the same folder can get changed in unexpected manner.

To fix this we need to do a rights reassignment. Or a Windows version of chmod + chown commands. Come the icacls command.

Run this in Administrative Command Prompt:

icacls "%UserProfile%\Desktop" /t /grant everyone:R "%UserName%":R System:F Administrators:F

This command would use Environment Variables:

  • %UserProfile% This is the Windows User Home Directory
  • %UserName% This is User Name of the current logged in User.

Note

To execute the above command the user needs to be in the Administrators Group.

The /t switch does sub-directory level application of permissions.

In case there is issues with inheritance of permissions use this command in Administrative Command Prompt.

icacls "Full path of file or folder" /inheritance:d

Here is an easy to use command that helps fix current directory permissions and all things under it:

icacls .\ /t /grant everyone:R "%UserName%":R System:F Administrators:F

docs.title: Auto-launching ssh-agent on MSYS2
docs.text:
Reference: https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/working-with-ssh-key-passphrases#auto-launching-ssh-agent-on-git-for-windows

You can run ssh-agent automatically when you open bash or Git shell. Copy the following lines and paste them into your ~/.profile or ~/.bashrc file in Git shell:

env=~/.ssh/agent.env

agent_load_env () { test -f "$env" && . "$env" >| /dev/null ; }

agent_start () {
    (umask 077; ssh-agent >| "$env")
    . "$env" >| /dev/null ; }

agent_load_env

# agent_run_state: 0=agent running w/ key; 1=agent w/o key; 2=agent not running
agent_run_state=$(ssh-add -l >| /dev/null 2>&1; echo $?)

if [ ! "$SSH_AUTH_SOCK" ] || [ $agent_run_state = 2 ]; then
    agent_start
    ssh-add
elif [ "$SSH_AUTH_SOCK" ] && [ $agent_run_state = 1 ]; then
    ssh-add
fi

unset env

Its better to use the Windows SSH since its integrated into the OS well and also works with Git for windows.

docs.title: Batch file Parameters
docs.text:
• %0: pathname of batch script itself
  • %1....%9: reference argument by number
  • %*: refers to all the arguments e.g. %1 %2 %3 %4 %5 ...%255
  • expansion modifiers
    • %~f1: expand %1 to a fully qualified path name e.g. c:\utils\MyFile.txt
    • %~d1: expand %1 to a drive letter only e.g. c:
    • %~p1: expand %1 to a path only including trailing \ e.g. \utils\
    • %~n1: expand %1 to a file Name without file extension or path - MyFile or if only a path is present, with no trailing backslash, the last folder in that path.
    • %~x1: expand %1 to a file eXtension only - .txt
    • %~s1: change the meaning of f, n, s and x to reference the Short 8.3 name (if it exists)
    • %~1: expand %1 removing any surrounding quotes "
    • %~a1: display the file attributes
    • %~t1: display the date/time
    • %~z1: display the file size
    • %~$PATH:1 search the PATH environment variable and expand %1 to the fully qualified name of the first match found
  • expansion modifiers can be combined
    • %~dp0 expand to full path of the batch script itself
    • %~dp1 expand %1 to a drive letter and path only
    • %~sp1 expand %1 to a path shortened to 8.3 characters
    • %~nx2 expand %2 to a file name and extension only

docs.title: Markdown to PDF in Sublime Text
Markdown to PDF in Sublime Text
docs.text: Sublime setup to quickly convert Markdown files to PDF through LateX with pandoc. For more details on Pandoc.

docs.title: Install Markdown Preview
docs.text:
Search for Markdown Preview and click it, this will install a handy tool for you to preview your markdown files in your browser without much effort.

To use simply press C-P or Ctrl+Shift+p again and type in markdown, select Markdown Preview and select browser.

docs.title: What is pandoc ?
docs.text:
If you need to convert files from one markup format into another, pandoc is your swiss-army knife. pandoc can convert documents in markdown, reStructuredText, textile, HTML, DocBook, LaTeX, MediaWiki markup, TWiki markup, OPML, Emacs Org-Mode, Txt2Tags, Microsoft Word docx, LibreOffice ODT, EPUB, or Haddock markup.

You download pandoc from here: http://pandoc.org/installing.html

You will need pandoc to convert your Markdown files to PDF files.

Heck, you might even want to try and search for pandoc in the Sublime Package Control and install the plugin. This should allow you to convert your files as well. Since this wasn't working for me at all and since I really couldn't get my head around it, I decided to make a custom build option for Sublime.

docs.title: Custom Sublime Build
docs.text:
First off we need to create a new Sublime-Build. Go to Tools > Build System > New Build System ...

This opens a file, replace the content with: 

{
    "shell_cmd": "pandoc -o \"$file.pdf\" \"$file\" && open -a Preview \"$file.pdf\"",
    "selector": "text.html.markdown",
    "path": "/usr/texbin:$PATH"
}

If you're not on a Mac: 

{
    "shell_cmd": "pandoc -o \"$file.pdf\" \"$file\"",
    "selector": "text.html.markdown",
    "path": "/usr/texbin:$PATH"
}

Save your new custom build to Sublime Text 4/Packages/User and name it as you desire. Now after saving go back to Tools > Build System and select your new build.

Now whenever you are writing your markdown and wish to convert it to PDF just press C-b or <f7> and it will convert it on the spot.

PS: If you wish to edit your custom build, you can find your build at this location on a Mac: ~/Library/Application Support/Sublime Text 4/Packages/User/

docs.title: Custom template (optional) LaTeX
docs.text:
Grab your custom LaTeX template and edit your custom build that you made in the previous step. 

{
    "shell_cmd": "pandoc --template=\"/Users/User/.pandoc/default.latex\" -o \"$file.pdf\" \"$file\" && open -a Preview \"$file.pdf\"" ,
    "selector": "text.html.markdown",
    "path": "/usr/texbin:$PATH"
}

Where User is your Username of your Macbook and 'default.latex' is the name of your LaTeX template. I grabbed my template from: https://github.com/jgm/pandoc-templates/blob/master/default.latex

After the first line starting with \documentclass, you can start writing your custom packages / fonts as you desire.

Here's an example of what was added on line 2 to start off with:

%%%%%%%%%%% HELVETICA %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%\usepackage[scaled=0.86]{helvet}
%\renewcommand\familydefault{\sfdefault}
%\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}

%%%%%%%%%%% OPEN SANS %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%\usepackage[default,osfigures,scale=0.8]{opensans}
%\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}

%%%%%%%%%%% QUATTROCENTO %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%\usepackage[sfdefault]{quattrocento}
%\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}

%%%%%%%%%%% LAYOUT %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\usepackage[english]{babel}
\usepackage{blindtext, fontenc, setspace}
\usepackage[margin=2.5cm]{geometry}

Just remove the % from the font you wish to use. For more fonts go to: http://www.tug.dk/FontCatalogue/sansseriffonts.html

docs.title: Sublime Text Snippets
docs.text:
Sublime Documentation https://www.sublimetext.com/docs/completions.html#snippets

Sublime Unofficial Documentation https://docs.sublimetext.io/guide/extensibility/snippets.html

Source https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/how-to-create-snippets-in-sublime-text/

  • Go to the Tools menu
  • Go to the Developer option and click on New Snippet. A Snippet file will be open with some pre-written code with .sublime-snippet extension.
  • Add your snippet inside the ![CDATA[ section. The ${1} are the tab stops for updating or predefined values.
  • Enable the <TabTrigger> This would be the trigger binding.
  • In case you need enable the <scope> This would narrow down the locations from where the snippet can be triggered. You can find the scope from Tools->Developer->Show Scope Name or press Ctrl+Alt+Shift+p. Copy the scope name and paste into the <scope> location.
  • Finally Save the file.

Typically the files are stored under the Package/User directory of the Sublime Text configuration.

On Linux its Typically ~/.config/sublime-text/Packages/User/ directory.

Here is the syntax from a Markdown Snippet file:

<snippet>
    <content><![CDATA[

----
<!-- Footer Begins Here -->
## Links

- [Back to Root Document](../README.md)

]]></content>
    <!-- Optional: Set a tabTrigger to define how to trigger the snippet -->
    <tabTrigger>mml0</tabTrigger>
    <!-- Optional: Set a scope to limit where the snippet will trigger -->
    <scope>text.html.markdown</scope>
</snippet>

docs.title: Solution for Windows 10 2024-10 Security Update
docs.text:
There are 2 solutions:

  1. Easy way use a Script provided.
  2. Manually do the repartitioning.

Here is what the site says:

Workaround: It might be necessary to increase the size of the WinRE partition in order to avoid this issue and complete the installation. Note that 250 megabytes of free space is required in the recovery partition. Devices which do not have sufficient free space in the recovery partition can use a script to extend the partition size. A sample script has been provided in the documentation for adding an update package to WinRE, Extend the Windows RE Partition. Guidance to manually change the WinRE partition size can additionally be found in KB5028997: Instructions to manually resize your partition to install the WinRE update.

Next steps: We are working on a resolution and will provide an update in an upcoming release.

Here is the PDF Copy of the KB5028997: Instructions to manually resize your partition to install the WinRE update.

It's better to follow the Manual method since its easier.

docs.title: Manually Resizing WinRE aka Windows Recovery Partition
docs.text:
Open a CMD with Administrator privileges and get typing.

  1. Check Status of the WinRE

    reagentc /info

  2. First we disable the WinRE.

    reagentc /disable

  3. Shrink the OS partition and prepare the disk for a new recovery partition.

    a. Run Windows Partition manager for CMD

    diskpart

    b. List all disks on system:

    list disk

    c. Select the correct disk with Windows 10 OS:

    sel disk <OS disk index>

    d. List out the partitions in the currently selected disk

    list par

    e. Select the Windows OS partition.

    sel part <OS partition index>

    f. Shrink the size by 250MB for Windows 10 OS Partition.

    shrink desired=250 minimum=250

    g. Select the WinRE or the recovery partition.

    sel part <WinRE partition index>

    h. Delete the WinRE partition !DANGER!

    delete partition override

    Don't Exit the program we still got to go.

  4. Setup a new Windows Recovery partition.

    a. Check for GPT partition table

    list disk

    Check if there is an asterisk character (*) in the Gpt column. If there is an asterisk character (*), then the drive is GPT. Otherwise, the drive is MBR.

    b. For a GPT disk use the following:

    create partition primary id=de94bba4-06d1-4d40-a16a-bfd50179d6ac

    Then

    gpt attributes =0x8000000000000001

    This would setup for GPT.

    OR

    b. For MBR

    create partition primary id=27

    c. Finally Format the new Partition

    format quick fs=ntfs label=”Windows RE tools”

  5. Confirm the Windows Recovery partition is indeed created:

    list vol

  6. Finally its time to Exit diskpart program.

    exit

  7. Re-enable the Windows Recovery partition and its feature.

    reagentc /enable

  8. Check with WinRE Windows Recovery is working

    reagentc /info

Continue with the update installation now. It would work fine.

docs.title: UnattendedWinstall - Script to Debloat Windwows at Install time
docs.text:
Personalized Unattended Answer Files that helps automatically de-bloat and customize Windows 10 & 11 during the installation process.

https://github.com/memstechtips/UnattendedWinstall

Download the latest version of autounattend.xml file and store it in the Root of the Windows USB install media.

https://github.com/memstechtips/UnattendedWinstall/releases/latest

There is also a UWScript.ps1 file that actually reapply or undo the changes done by the autounattend.xml file.

Usage of UWScript.ps1 Script

Use the UWScript.ps1 file once Windows is installed to reapply or revert settings in case Windows Update resets some of the settings or if you encounter any issues. It can also be used to achieve a similar experience to UnattendedWinstall on an existing Windows installation without reinstalling Windows.

Before Running the Script

Ensure you open PowerShell as an administrator. Additionally, set the execution policy to allow script execution by running the following command:

Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted

Running PowerShell with elevated permissions and enabling script execution will ensure that UWScript.ps1 can apply the necessary system changes.

UnattendedWinstall

UnattendedWinstall has been tested and optimized for personal use. For those interested in customizing further, create your own answer file following this video guide.

docs.title: Install Windows into a Drive or VHDX file using DISM method
docs.text:
This need the Windows Installation Media to access the WIM or ESD Image.

Install windows using the DSIM method in Administrative Command Prompt:

Dism /Apply-Image /ImageFile:D:\sources\install.wim /index:1 /ApplyDir:V:\

Here the D:\sources\install.wim is the Install ISO mounted in D: drive letter.

And the VHDX mounted at V: drive letter.

Note: This would work for both GPT and MBR especially for Windows 7 since it does not support UEFI.

Finally we need to add the Windows to the Boot Menu entry:

bcdboot V:\Windows

docs.title: Microsoft Knowledge base article on DISM way on installing Windows
docs.text:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/boot-to-vhd--native-boot--add-a-virtual-hard-disk-to-the-boot-menu?view=windows-11

PDF Version of the same.

Here is the detailed command for bcdboot in UEFI BIOS System:

bcdboot v:\windows /s S: /f UEFI

This would add the V: drive letter installation to S: where the EFI partition is located in.

Similarly for Legacy BIOS system:

bcdboot v:\windows /s S: /f BIOS

In this case the MBR is on the S: drive.

Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\TimeZoneInformation]
"RealTimeIsUniversal"=dword:00000001

docs.title: Hiren’s BootCD PE
docs.text:
Homepage: https://www.hirensbootcd.org/

Download https://www.hirensbootcd.org/download/

This is an indispensable tool for managing windows installations.

Hiren’s BootCD PE (Preinstallation Environment) is a restored edition of Hiren’s BootCD based on Windows 11 PE x64. Given the absence of official updates after November 2012, the PE version is currently under development by the fans of Hiren’s BootCD. It includes a carefully chosen set of the best free tools, designed for modern computers that support UEFI booting and need at least 4 GB of RAM.

Equipped with these invaluable tools, you can address various computer-related problems. Notably, it does not include any pirated software; instead, it exclusively contains free and legal software.

If your computer does not support a regular Windows 11 installation, it will likely boot with the Windows 11 PE version, as Windows PE versions have significantly lower hardware requirements. For instance, if your computer boots with the Windows 10 PE version, it is highly probable that it will also boot with the Windows 11 PE version.

Upon booting, the PE version attempts to install drivers for essential components such as graphics, sound, wireless and Ethernet cards for your hardware, facilitating connection to a WIFI or Ethernet network.

docs.title: Bypass Internet Connection requirement at Install
docs.text:
There is a bit of jugglery to be performed to get the connection with internet requirement disabled.

We would need to keep terminating a particular process oobenetworkconnectionflow.exe during install.

When the question is asked in the setup process to connect to Internet press Shift + F10 together. This would open the Administrator Terminal.

taskkill /f /IM oobenetworkconnectionflow.exe

This would lead to the setup showing some thing went wrong. Don't worry - Click on Retry and setup would again ask for Network.

Use Alt + Tab to switch back to the Administrator Terminal and type the terminating command again.

These steps might take several times to repeat. Till you get the Who will use this .... Name prompt.

Once you get to this point Alt + Tab to the Administrator Terminal and exit it.

The setup would continue as usual.

docs.title: Solution 1 : Restart Explorer
docs.text:
This might be just the easiest solution but effective sometimes.

  • Press Ctrl + Shift + Esc This would open Task Manger
  • Click on the Processes Tab
  • If the process are not sorted by name then press Name column once. This would start to show the Apps (..) and Background processes.
  • Now under Apps find Windows Explorer and terminate all Tasks.
  • Finally scroll below in Windows processes find Windows Explorer. There might be multiple instances.
  • Restart the process Windows Explorer under the Windows processes.

This would be band aid fix. If this works then you need to Restart your PC as its memory corrupted in Standby or Sleep or Hibernation modes.

docs.title: Solution 2 : Start Up cleaning (Restart Needed)
docs.text:
In this solution we can find the problematic services or Virus that is causing our problem.

  • Open the Run Prompt using Meta + R or Windows Key + R combination.
  • Type the command msconfig and click ok. This would open System Configuration window.
  • Go to the Services tab and check Hide All Microsoft Services
  • This gives a list of start-up services running in the PC. If you find any suspicious service deactivate/un-check it.
  • Finally restart the PC to see if the problem is gone.

Diagnosis 1: In case some thing breaks and the problem got solved the possibly some software installed had caused the issue.

Diagnosis 2: Problem is not solved and something breaks then we would need to re-enable that service we deactivated at startup.

Diagnosis 3: Problem is Solved and everything works fine then we found the specific service that has caused the issue. In this case find out more about that particular service from Internet. And if there are any way to permanently remove them from the PC.

docs.title: Solution 3 : Resource Checker Scan and Fix (Restart Needed)
docs.text:
In case some system files have got corrupt or misplaced we need to fix that.

  1. Scan Fix

    • Open an Administrative Command Prompt
    • Type the Command: sfc /scannow
    • This would try to fix the problems with the Windows system files.
    • Restart the System after the command completes.

  2. Check Disk

    • It might be a good idea to check all your disks for any errors.
    • Use this command in Administrative Command Prompt chkdsk /f /r /b
    • This would run for all the disks in the system.

  3. Microsoft Resource Checker Software help

This is the `sfc` command:

    C:\Windows\System32>sfc --help

    Microsoft (R) Windows (R) Resource Checker Version 6.0
    Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

    Scans the integrity of all protected system files and replaces incorrect versions with
    correct Microsoft versions.

    SFC [/SCANNOW] [/VERIFYONLY] [/SCANFILE=<file>] [/VERIFYFILE=<file>]
        [/OFFWINDIR=<offline windows directory> /OFFBOOTDIR=<offline boot directory> [/OFFLOGFILE=<log file path>]]

    /SCANNOW        Scans integrity of all protected system files and repairs files with
                    problems when possible.
    /VERIFYONLY     Scans integrity of all protected system files. No repair operation is
                    performed.
    /SCANFILE       Scans integrity of the referenced file, repairs file if problems are
                    identified. Specify full path <file>
    /VERIFYFILE     Verifies the integrity of the file with full path <file>.  No repair
                    operation is performed.
    /OFFBOOTDIR     For offline repair, specify the location of the offline boot directory
    /OFFWINDIR      For offline repair, specify the location of the offline windows directory
    /OFFLOGFILE     For offline repair, optionally enable logging by specifying a log file path

    e.g.

            sfc /SCANNOW
            sfc /VERIFYFILE=c:\windows\system32\kernel32.dll
            sfc /SCANFILE=d:\windows\system32\kernel32.dll /OFFBOOTDIR=d:\ /OFFWINDIR=d:\windows
            sfc /SCANFILE=d:\windows\system32\kernel32.dll /OFFBOOTDIR=d:\ /OFFWINDIR=d:\windows /OFFLOGFILE=c:\log.txt
            sfc /VERIFYONLY

docs.title: Force windows to use one network/WiFi adapter
docs.text:
Reference:

  • https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/how-to-force-windows-to-use-one-network-adapter/dc4e36aa-94f5-433b-93a2-3da7d46a0e5d

Here are the Steps:

  • Open Settings.
  • Click on Network & Internet.
  • Click on Status.
  • Click the Change Adapter options item.
  • Right-click the network adapter you want to prioritize, and select Properties
  • Select the Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) item.
  • Click the Properties button.
  • In the "General" tab, click the Advanced button.
  • Clear the Automatic metric check-box.
  • In the "Interface metric" field assign a priority value for the adapter.
    • Quick Tip: The lower the metric number means higher priority,
    • and a higher number indicates lower priority.
  • Click the OK button.
  • Click the OK button again.
  • Click the Close button.

Additionally we disable a particular adapter:

  • Computer Management, Devices, right click your on board device and select "disable this device"

docs.title: Rufus USB Creation tool for Windows
Rufus USB Creation tool for Windows
docs.text:
Homepage https://rufus.ie/en/

Sources https://github.com/pbatard/rufus

Rufus is a utility that helps format and create bootable USB flash drives, such as USB keys/pendrives, memory sticks, etc.

It helps to customize Windows 11 or Windows 10 installation. Also directly downloads the ISO if needed from windows download sources.

It also works well for Linux OS images.

It can be especially useful for cases where:

  • you need to create USB installation media from bootable ISOs (Windows, Linux, UEFI, etc.)
  • you need to work on a system that doesn't have an OS installed
  • you need to flash a BIOS or other firmware from DOS
  • you want to run a low-level utility

docs.title: A SMARTER WAY TO DUAL BOOT WINDOWS...
docs.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7JBFJuA5QsM

This youtube video opens up possibility of keeping your existing windows installation and then build custom windows installs on top it.

This method of creating Virtual Disks VHDX helps to keep multiple version of Windows on the same drive and same copies as well.

Backing up of the Install is just copying out the .vhdx file.

Another key advantage is that THis allows to port the Windows install between PC if such a thing is supported. Meaning that if you don't need too many drivers to be installed for the windows setup, you can port the install between PCs. This was impossible earlier but with this technique it will get enabled.

In this demo, I show you a cool way to install multiple Windows operating systems on the same PC. No virtualization and No disk partitioning required.

It's simple to add or remove an operating system at any time.

The tools needed for the job are:

  1. diskpart This is the windows Partitioning utility available in Windows and Installation Media. We can use the Windows Disk Management to also create the VHDX but this one would be much universal.
  2. bcd-tools These are the collection of bcdlist and bcdedit That would allow to rename the Windows installs on the Virtual Disks
  3. msconfig This is used to reconfigure the boot priority and timing.

Issues with Windows 11 24H2 and Above
