docs.title: To Create Virtual Disks and Enable Booting
docs.text:
Let us now look at the process of partitioning and creating the VHDX files.

You need to enter the Windows Setup and then press Shift + F10 to enter the Administrative command prompt. This would help to run various system commands.

We would be using the diskpart utility that comes build it even with the installation media.

This would allow us to partition the disk in the correct way.

For more information refer to the documents on diskpart utility.

We would later use the bcdboot utility or the EasyBCD utility in adjusting the boot loader manipulation.

Here is how our disk partition would look like:

# Partition Size (MB) Purpose 1 EFI System 2048 Boot partition used in UEFI systems. 2 MSR Partition 128 Secret Windows MSR Partition 3 Host-Drive All space This is the location for VHDX file storage. 4 ... ... Any other partitions that you need or Linux

This below mention procedure needs to done only once to create one bootable VHDX installed Windows OS. For future ones refer to the Create additional VHDX guide.

docs.title: diskpart commands for a UEFI BIOS Systems to create Initial VHDX Storage
docs.text: We would be creating the required partition and configuring a disk to store all our VHDX file calling it VHDX Storage.

docs.title: 1. Start diskpart
docs.text:
To enter diskpart utility:

diskpart

docs.title: 2. List all Disks available
docs.text: list disk

docs.title: 3. Select a Particular Disk where the Virtual Disks would be stored
docs.text:
select disk 0

How to chose the disk

This might be daunting task if you are not aware of which disk to operate on. The first clues might lie in the Size of the Disk. The next on might be the Disk Names etc.

docs.title: 4. Clear out the Partitions and prepare the Disk
docs.text:
This step is needed since we are using entire disk for the VHDX storage.

In-case its only a single partition on an already in use disk then DO Not follow through this step.

clean
convert gpt

DANGER!! This command deletes all partitions on the selected Disk. Then creates a gpt partition table in the same disk.

docs.title: 5. Creating the EFI Partition
docs.text:
Again this step is needed only if you wish to use your entire disk for the VHDX storage and do not have any existing EFI partitions.

Create the EFI boot partition:

create partition efi size=200
format fs=fat32 label="System"

In case you wish to also install Linux in a multi-boot configuration or many Windows variants then set the size=2048.

This would make the EFI Partition much bigger to host multiple Linux OS.

Adjust the size and found optimal to use size=200.

docs.title: 6. MSR Partition
docs.text:
Again this one is a mandate in most cases. As its some mysterious thing need by Windows to identify the drives.

Create the MSR needed for Windows installs:

create partition msr size=128

docs.title: 7. Primary Storage partition for VHDX storage
docs.text:
Finally create the Primary Partition where we would be storing our VHDX files. We would name this as Host-Drive to easily distinguish the drive. And finally also assign a drive letter so that we can install Windows.

create partition primary
format fs=ntfs quick label="Host-Drive"
assign
Note that the last assign command would mount / attach the created VHDX Storage partition like into C: or D: or any such Drive Letter.

We can also limit the size of this Host-Drive with the following command.

create partition primary size=512000
format fs=ntfs quick label="Host-Drive"
assign

This would create a 500GB partition.

Note: All sizes are in Mega Bytes. The EFI partition is bigger to allow more OS to be installed.

In order to ascertain which Drive Letter was assigned :

list volume

This would list our Host-Drive partition also.

docs.title: 8. diskpart commands to create a virtual disk
docs.text:
Note that we are assuming that C: is our Host-Drive partition. We found about out this earlier using the list vol command.

create vdisk file=C:\filename.vhdx maximum=81920
select vdisk file=C:\filename.vhd
attach vdisk

Change C:\ to whatever drive letter you have for your Host-Drive partition is assigned on the hard disk.

Change 81920 to whatever size you want your disk to be (in MB) or just enter size to the nearest 1000, e.g 80000

You can use an online calculator if you want to be exact.

https://www.gbmb.org/gb-to-mb

docs.title: Using diskpart To create a Expandable Virtual Disk
docs.text:
create vdisk file=C:\filename.vhdx maximum=81920 type=expandable
select vdisk file=C:\filename.vhd
attach vdisk

This would initially create a small file but then expand to a much bigger as the OS and files are installed over time.

docs.title: 9. Exit diskpart and Continue with Windows Install
docs.text:
Now that the virtual disk is created you can exit diskpart.

To exit diskpart utility on prompt:

DISKPART> exit

Finally continue the Windows 11 install.

While selecting partition where to install choose the partition with VHDX Partition size of 80GB or what ever you set earlier. Since this is the VHDX file we mounted earlier. The windows will then be installed inside this file. Don't worry after booting you will also be able to see the Host-Drive without any issues.

docs.title: diskpart commands for a Legacy BIOS Systems to create Initial VHDX Storage
docs.text:
Future and Legacy BIOS

This information is provided for compatibility sake only. Its most certain that the Legacy BIOS system would got completely obsolete and archaic.

Similar commands again be aware of what this might lead to.

list disk
select disk 0
clean
create partition primary size=100
format fs=ntfs quick label="System"
assign
active
create partition primary
format fs=ntfs quick label="Host-Drive"
assign
list vol

These are similar to the once for UEFI with some small changes.

docs.title: diskpart commands for the UEFI BIOS System to Create Next VHDX installs
docs.text:
This is assuming that you have already completed the creation of the Host-Drive for VHDX Storage as explained the previous section.

You need to enter the Windows Setup and then press Shift + F10 to enter the Administrative command prompt. This would help to run various system commands.

docs.title: 1. Start diskpart
docs.text:
This time the flow would be slightly different so don't overlook the steps.

diskpart

docs.title: 2. Check the Volumes and Find the Host-Drive
docs.text:
list volume

This would give an idea of the volumes that have been mounted and what Drive Letter has been assigned to them.

In these you would find the volume named Host-Drive. This is where we are going to create our VHDX files. Make a note of the Drive Letter for the Host-Drive.

docs.title: 3. Create the VHDX and Attach is it
docs.text:
create vdisk file=C:\filename.vhdx maximum=81920 type=expandable
select vdisk file=C:\filename.vhd
attach vdisk

This time we are going with an expandable one with familiar 80GB size.

docs.title: 4. Exit diskpart and continue the install
docs.text:
exit

This would close the diskpart and bring you back to the terminal prompt. You can now close this Administrative Command prompt.

Back in the Installation make sure select the 80GB Partition.

docs.title: 5. Special Note on the Boot Order
docs.text:
Whenever a new OS is install in this new VHDX we created here, its order becomes the first to start at boot.

This means that when the install completes and you reboot into Boot Loader Screen aka Metro Boot Screen you will observe the the current OS becomes the new default OS that would start. Its a good idea to uniquely rename each of the OS as detailed later.

docs.title: Change the Windows Boot Name in the Metro Boot Loader Screen
docs.text:
First boot into the desired OS and then use the following command in an Administrative Command Prompt:

bcdedit /set {current} description "Windows 10 Demo"

This would change the OS name for the current OS. You should see a Operation completed successfully as the output of this command.

One needs to boot into each of the OS installed and then change the names.

Or there is an easier way.

EasyBCD Saves the day.

Hiren’s BootCD PE

This utility is available by default in all the editions of the Hiren’s BootCD PE. It might not be needed to install every time. You can just boot into the image and then do the manipulation based on the install order and the last installed instance.

docs.title: diskpart commands to increase the size of a virtual disk
docs.text:
Open the diskpart tool in a Administrative Command Prompt.

  1. Select the VHDX file that need to expanded.

    select vdisk file=D:\xxxxxxx.VHDX

    Where D:\xxxxx.VHDX is the path and filename of the virtual disk you want to increase.

  2. Expand the Disk size first to the Desired amount :

    expand vdisk maximum=102400

    Change 102400 to whatever size in MB you want to increase it to

  3. Attach the Disk

    attach vdisk
list volume
select volume x:

    Change x: to whatever drive letter the attached virtual disk has got

  4. And finally extend the volume:

    extend

  5. Exit diskpart and reboot to make sure the changes take effect.

docs.title: Remove an OS that's not needed the VHDX way
docs.text:
1. First delete the .VHDX file for the corresponding OS.

  2. Next open an Administrator Command Prompt and type:

    msconfig

    This can also be done in a Run Prompt by pressing Win+r Keys. 3. Then in the MS Config window in the Boot tab - select the OS entry to be removed and press Delete button.

  3. Then press Apply button to store this setting. And finally click on OK.

  4. You would be prompted to Restart the system, its recommended to do so for the changes to take effect.

docs.title: Backing up an OS installed in the VHDX Way
docs.text:
The benefits of using a .VHDX file is that its a file on the disk that can be easily backed up and restored as needed.

Just boot up into one of the other OS, different from the one you wish to backup.

You can now just copy the file into a different disk for backup and restoration if needed in future.

Optionally you can also use some utility such as zip, tar or 7z to archive the os to the different drive to store multiple versions and os for saving some space.

docs.title: Restoring an OS from Backup in the VHDX Way
docs.text:
1. Boot into any of the OS other than the one to restore.

  2. Copy back the .VHDX file or extract its archive back to the Host-Disk Drive from where all OS boot. Make sure that it does not overwrite any of the existing images.

  3. The mount the .VHDX file into the OS using the Disk Management utility. In the Disk Management click on the Action Menu -> Attach VHD. Keep a note of the Drive letter its mounted to.

  4. Next open a Administrative Command Prompt and type

    bcdboot E:\Windows

    This would add the VHDX mounted to the E: drive letter as a boot entry.

docs.title: Easier way to Create the .VHDX files from Disk Management Utility
docs.text:
1. Open the Disk Management Utility in one of the OSs you can boot into.
  2. Click on the Action Menu -> Create VHD This would open the Creation dialog.
  3. First need to specify the location and Filename .VHDX file
  4. Next we need to specify its size this time you can select the units for specifying the size.
  5. Next we need to choose the Virtual disk format this needs to be the VHDX as its the latest and better one.
  6. Next will be the type of Disk - New VHDX support dynamic disk and its recommended by default. This would create a disk that would increase in size as needed and not occupy the whole space at once.
  7. Click OK on the Creation dialog and then the Disk would be created and appear now in the Disk Management
  8. Next Right-click on the Disk and click Initialize. This would open the Initialize Disk dialog.
  9. Select the GPT partition type as its and click on OK. This would allow you to create partitions on the disk.
  10. Next inside the new initialized Disk area Right click and select New Simple Volume... This would open the New Volume creation Wizard. Go through the process and create the NTFS disk to access the whole of the space on the new disk created.
  11. This new partition would automatically be mounted and assigned a drive letter. Make a note of the letter and keep it handy for the next commands.

docs.title: Automate the Out of Box Experience and create a local user in Windows 11 Pro Audit Mode
docs.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dEva8T_NTAI

Go to Audit Mode by pressing Ctrl + Shift + F3 during the out of box setup stage.

Edit the script to use your language/region, for example if you are in the United States you would use en-US instead of en-GB.

For a full list of region codes, use this link :

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/openspecs/office_standards/ms-oe376/6c085406-a698-4e12-9d4d-c3b0ee3dbc4a

You should also set the time zone for where you are.

For a full list of time zones, see this link:

You should also replace the username and password for the local account you want to use.

In this example script, I used a user called Admin and set the password to Password123. Also the Administrator account is set with password AdminPass123=.

You can also set the password for the local Administrator account although the Administrator account is disabled by default.

unattend.txt
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<unattend xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:unattend">
    <settings pass="oobeSystem">
        <component name="Microsoft-Windows-International-Core" processorArchitecture="amd64" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" language="neutral" versionScope="nonSxS" xmlns:wcm="http://schemas.microsoft.com/WMIConfig/2002/State" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">

            <SystemLocale>en-US</SystemLocale>
            <UILanguage>en-US</UILanguage>
            <UILanguageFallback>en-US</UILanguageFallback>

        </component>
        <component name="Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Setup" processorArchitecture="amd64" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" language="neutral" versionScope="nonSxS" xmlns:wcm="http://schemas.microsoft.com/WMIConfig/2002/State" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">

                <HideEULAPage>true</HideEULAPage>
                <HideLocalAccountScreen>true</HideLocalAccountScreen>
                <HideOEMRegistrationScreen>true</HideOEMRegistrationScreen>
                <HideOnlineAccountScreens>true</HideOnlineAccountScreens>
                <HideWirelessSetupInOOBE>true</HideWirelessSetupInOOBE>
                <NetworkLocation>Work</NetworkLocation>
                <ProtectYourPC>3</ProtectYourPC>
            </OOBE>
            <UserAccounts>
                <AdministratorPassword>
                    <Value>AdminPass123=</Value>
                    <PlainText>true</PlainText>
                </AdministratorPassword>

                    <LocalAccount wcm:action="add">
                        <Password>
                            <Value>Password123</Value>

docs.title: 1. Create a Local user in the Audit Mode
docs.text:
Open a Administrator Command Prompt from the start menu.

To create a user called madhav with their password as Password123:

net user madhav Password123 /add

For more details on the net user command refer to he Microsoft Documentation:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2012-r2-and-2012/cc771865(v=ws.11)

Next we set the Administrators privilege for madhav account:

net localgroup administrators madhav /add

For more details on the net localgroup command refer to the Microsoft Documentation:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2012-r2-and-2012/cc725622(v=ws.11)

You can now set the Administrator User password as AdminPass123=:

net user Administrator AdminPass123=

This would set the Password for the Administrator account.

docs.title: 2. Login using the Local user in the Audit Mode to perform SysPrep
docs.text:
After User creation and configuration is completed log out of the Administrator User and Login as madav or admin which ever you just created.

Again, open a Administrator Command Prompt from the start menu.

Change directory to the sysprep folder:

cd c:\Windows\System32\Sysprep

More details on the Sysprep tool from Microsoft Documentation:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/sysprep--generalize--a-windows-installation?view=windows-11

Now there are two ways to Sysprep the images:

  1. Capture a generalized image to be deployable on multiple other machines
sysprep /generalize /oobe /shutdown /unattend:d:\unattend.txt

This would remove the uniqueness of the image and prepare it with shutting down.

  1. To only automate the OOBE on the machine (preferred):
sysprep /oobe /reboot /unattend:d:\unattend.txt

PC will then restart and complete the OOBE without any prompt from the user.

Another simple method for installing Windows 11 to unsupported hardware.

docs.title: Microsoft Deployment Lab Script
docs.text:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions-sample-scripts?view=windows-11

Look at the CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt Script:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions-sample-scripts?view=windows-11#createpartitions-uefitxt

This would help to Partition the Disk into desired partitions using this command:

dispart /s CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt

Note: This might need to be customized for your desired PC or Disk Configuration.

CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt
rem == CreatePartitions-UEFI.txt ==
rem == These commands are used with DiskPart to
rem    create four partitions
rem    for a UEFI/GPT-based PC.
rem    Adjust the partition sizes to fill the drive
rem    as necessary. ==
select disk 0
clean
convert gpt
rem == 1. System partition =========================
create partition efi size=100
rem    ** NOTE: For Advanced Format 4Kn drives,
rem               change this value to size = 260 **
format quick fs=fat32 label="System"
assign letter="S"
rem == 2. Microsoft Reserved (MSR) partition =======
create partition msr size=16
rem == 3. Windows partition ========================
rem ==    a. Create the Windows partition ==========
create partition primary
rem ==    b. Create space for the recovery tools ===
rem       ** Update this size to match the size of
rem          the recovery tools (winre.wim)
rem          plus some free space.
shrink minimum=500
rem ==    c. Prepare the Windows partition =========
format quick fs=ntfs label="Windows"
assign letter="W"
rem === 4. Recovery partition ======================
create partition primary
format quick fs=ntfs label="Recovery"
assign letter="R"
set id="de94bba4-06d1-4d40-a16a-bfd50179d6ac"
gpt attributes=0x8000000000000001
list volume
exit

Note: Make sure to copy this file to your windows installation USB. It would needed when the Windows Setup is running.

docs.title: Execute the Partition Script and DISM technique
docs.text: In the Windows 11 Installation press Shift + F10 to enter the Administrator Command Prompt.

docs.title: Make the partitions using the Script and Diskpart
docs.text:
Change to the drive you have your Windows Installation media, and run Diskpart utility:

d:

diskpart \s "disprep.txt"

Here the diskprep.txt contains the configuration done above.

In case you wish to edit this file it would be made possible using notepad.exe.

Type in command to edit the diskprep.txt file:

notepad d:\diskprep.txt

Make sure that your Path to the file is correct as per the Windows install USB disk drive letter.

docs.title: Use the DISM program to install the Correct version of the Windows 11 directly
docs.text:
Use the command to list the OS Classification and Version available by using the command:

dism /get-wiminfo /wimfile:"d:\sources\install.esd"

Note: The drive letter for USB containing the Windows 11 Install source should be correct.

Find out the Windows types using the Index: X number in the list that appears.

Finally we are ready to begin the installation:

dism /apply-image /imagefile:"d:\sources\install.esd" /index:6 /applydir:w:\

This would install the index 6 which might be Windows 11 Pro into the w:\ drive mounted by our earlier step of partitioning using the script.

docs.title: Make the HDD Bootable for the currently installed Windows 11
docs.text:
We select the w:\ drive to boot:

bcdboot w:\windows /s s: /f UEFI

This would make the current install bootable and store the UEFI boot in s:\ drive. This was created in the earlier partitioning step.

docs.title: mosquitto MQTT Broker https://mosquitto.org/
docs.text:
Most widely used broker. We have a Raspberry Pi details of the same as well as the desktop IoT setup.

Mosquitto Test Broker https://test.mosquitto.org/

Supports all types of MQTT Connections and any number of devices. This service is Slow due to the type of hosting hence can be used only for testing purposes only.

The server listens on the following ports:

  • 1883 : MQTT, unencrypted, unauthenticated
  • 1884 : MQTT, unencrypted, authenticated
  • 8883 : MQTT, encrypted, unauthenticated
  • 8884 : MQTT, encrypted, client certificate required
  • 8885 : MQTT, encrypted, authenticated
  • 8886 : MQTT, encrypted, unauthenticated
  • 8887 : MQTT, encrypted, server certificate deliberately expired
  • 8080 : MQTT over WebSockets, unencrypted, unauthenticated
  • 8081 : MQTT over WebSockets, encrypted, unauthenticated
  • 8090 : MQTT over WebSockets, unencrypted, authenticated
  • 8091 : MQTT over WebSockets, encrypted, authenticate

The authenticated listeners require a username / password:

  • rw / readwrite : read/write access to the # topic hierarchy
  • ro / readonly : read only access to the # topic hierarchy
  • wo / writeonly : write only access to the # topic hierarchy

docs.title: Initially Login as root
docs.text:
ssh root@your_server_ip

Note: Make sure your SSH keys are enabled in the SSH Key Agent or are installed in the .ssh path.

In case you wish to use a special key then use this command instead:

ssh -i path/to/your/ssh-key root@your_server_ip

Also make sure to add this as an entry in your ssh-config if needed:

Host root-do-deb-sever
    HostName your_server_ip
    User root
    IdentityFile path/to/your/ssh-key

docs.text:
sudo adduser user_name

Assign it sudo privileges:

sudo usermod -aG sudo user_name

docs.title: Setting up Firewall
docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install ufw

Enable SSH:

sudo ufw limit OpenSSH

Enable the Firewall:

sudo ufw enable

Enable it to reloaded every time during startup:

sudo systemctl enable --now ufw

Check status of the ufw firewall:

sudo ufw status

docs.title: Enabling external SSH access to your user on Digital Ocean
docs.text:
Get the Authorized keys file for the SSH along with any keys loaded:

sudo cp -r /root/.ssh /home/user_name
sudo chown -R user_name:user_name /home/user_name/.ssh

Now on your side you can do this:

ssh user_name@your_server_ip

And add this as your ssh-config:

Host do-deb-sever
    HostName your_server_ip
    User user_name
    IdentityFile path/to/your/ssh-key

docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install nginx

docs.title: Adjust the Firewall to initially allow only HTTP traffic on Nginx
docs.text:
sudo ufw allow 'Nginx HTTP'

Check the firewall status:

sudo ufw status

Output:

Status: active

To                         Action      From
--                         ------      ----
OpenSSH                    LIMIT       Anywhere
Nginx HTTP                 ALLOW       Anywhere
OpenSSH (v6)               LIMIT       Anywhere (v6)
Nginx HTTP (v6)            ALLOW       Anywhere (v6)

docs.title: Check the State of the Default Web Server
docs.text:
sudo systemctl status nginx

Get your IP Address:

ip addr show eth0 | grep inet | awk '{ print $2; }' | sed 's/\/.*$//'

Now in the WebBrowser type:

http://your_server_ip

This should show the initial Nginx Page.

Good job your default Nginx server is now running. This the first step to check if the thing is working or not.

docs.title: Useful Nginx Commands
docs.text:
Temporarily stop the Nginx server:

sudo systemctl stop nginx

Start the Nginx server which was stopped:

sudo systemctl start nginx

Easy restart of the Nginx server:

sudo systemctl restart nginx

Reload the configuration in Nginx server:

sudo systemctl reload nginx

Stop Nginx server from booting again, and not stop the current running server if any:

sudo systemctl disable nginx

Enable Nginx server to boot when machine is restarted:

sudo systemctl enable nginx

Verifying the Nginx Configuration, this makes sure if the files for Nginx are written correctly or not including their syntax:

sudo nginx -t

Output:

nginx: the configuration file /etc/nginx/nginx.conf syntax is ok
nginx: configuration file /etc/nginx/nginx.conf test is successful

docs.title: Setting up a Basic HTTP Page for a domain Name in Nginx
docs.text:
Note: Make sure that the Digital Ocean NameServer configuration are loaded in your_domain.com. Here is the DNS Documentation for Digital Ocean.

Note: Make sure that A records are added for your_domain.com such that you have:

  • A record with your_domain.com pointing to your server’s public IP address.
  • A record with *.your_domain.com pointing to your server’s public IP address as a wild card record.

Now setup the Nginx Server block for your_domain.com :

docs.title: 1. Create a hosting directory /var/www/your_domain.com/html
docs.text: sudo mkdir -p /var/www/your_domain.com/html

docs.title: 2. Enable the execute permission on the /var/www/your_domain.com/html directory
docs.text: sudo chmod -R 755 /var/www/your_domain.com

docs.title: 3. Create an initial index.html file for your domain
docs.text:
sudo nano /var/www/your_domain.com/html/index.html

HTML content:

<html>
    <head>
        <title>Welcome to your_domain</title>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1>Success! Your Nginx server is successfully configured for <em>your_domain</em>. </h1>
<p>This is a sample page.</p>
    </body>
</html>

docs.title: 4. Add the Domain to the Nginx Site available directory in /etc/nginx/sites-available
docs.text:
sudo nano /etc/nginx/sites-available/your_domain.com

This would open the Nginx configuration for your domain. Currently we need to configure the http end points to help us link to this website.

Here is the content:

server {
        listen 80;
        listen [::]:80;

        root /var/www/your_domain.com/html;
        index index.html index.htm index.nginx-debian.html;

        server_name your_domain.com www.your_domain.com;

        location / {
                try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
        }
}

docs.title: 5. Enable this configuration to be available:
docs.text:
sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/your_domain.com /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/

All the enabled sites are in the /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/ directory. There will be 2 entries now:

  • your_domain.com: Will respond to requests for your_domain.com and www.your_domain
  • default: Will respond to any requests on port 80 that do not match the other two blocks. We would later need to disable this

docs.title: 6. Enable the Listing of our website in Nginx configuration:
docs.text:
sudo nano /etc/nginx/nginx.conf

Find the line server_names_hash_bucket_size and uncomment it:

...
http {
    ...
    server_names_hash_bucket_size 64;
    ...
}

docs.title: Begin by getting the SSH Certificates for the Required domains
docs.text:
sudo certbot --nginx -d your_domain.com -d www.your_domain.com

This runs certbot with the --nginx plugin, using -d to specify the domain names we’d like the certificate to be valid for.

If this is your first time running certbot, you will be prompted to enter an email address and agree to the terms of service. After doing so, certbot will communicate with the Let’s Encrypt server, then run a challenge to verify that you control the domain you’re requesting a certificate for.

The configuration will be updated, and Nginx will reload to pick up the new settings. certbot will wrap up with a message telling you the process was successful and where your certificates are stored:

IMPORTANT NOTES:
 - Congratulations! Your certificate and chain have been saved at:
   /etc/letsencrypt/live/your_domain.com/fullchain.pem
   Your key file has been saved at:
   /etc/letsencrypt/live/your_domain.com/privkey.pem
   Your cert will expire on 2022-08-08. To obtain a new or tweaked
   version of this certificate in the future, simply run certbot again
   with the "certonly" option. To non-interactively renew *all* of
   your certificates, run "certbot renew"
 - If you like Certbot, please consider supporting our work by:

   Donating to ISRG / Let's Encrypt:   https://letsencrypt.org/donate
   Donating to EFF:                    https://eff.org/donate-le

Now incase you wish to have additional end points like api or load etc they too can be added to this same command:

sudo certbot --nginx -d your_domain.com -d www.your_domain.com -d api.your_domain.com -d load.your_domain.com

You can also do this later by Expanding the existing certificate.

sudo certbot renew --dry-run

If you see no errors, you’re all set. When necessary, Certbot will renew your certificates and reload Nginx to pick up the changes. If the automated renewal process ever fails, Let’s Encrypt will send a message to the email you specified, warning you when your certificate is about to expire.

docs.title: Fixing the Default Server
docs.text:
Reference: https://serverfault.com/questions/420351/best-way-to-prevent-default-server

PDF version of the same: PDF

Even though your HTTPS sever is ready there is still one thing pending the default server.

Remember we talked about this while listing out /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/ directory.

Edit the configuration for the default server:

sudo nano /etc/nginx/sites-available/default

Make sure it looks something like this:

# Default server configuration
#
server {
        listen 80 default_server;
        listen [::]:80 default_server;
        ....
        root /var/www/html;

        # Add index.php to the list if you are using PHP
        index index.html index.htm index.nginx-debian.html;

        server_name _;

        location / {
                # First attempt to serve request as file, then
                # as directory, then fall back to displaying a 404.
                try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
        }

        # Block the Default server from Responding
        ssl_reject_handshake on;
        return 444;
        ....

The lines ssl_reject_handshake on; and return 444; help to block any requests coming to the http://your_server_ip route.

docs.title: Tax back calculation or TDS Adjust Calculation
docs.text:
It's an important way to reverse calculate the cost of an item or job rate.

Here are the factors we would like to look into:

  • y The final sale price or the one Charged from customer
  • x The Cost price or Input price or the amount you wish to get after Tax / TDS deduction
  • T Total tax deducted
  • z The rate of Tax or TDS - This is typically a percentage value

Here is what we know:

  • y = x + T means that total or final sale price is the sum of the Cost price and Total tax deducted
  • T = y * Z means that Total tax deducted is the portion rate of Tax of the final sale price

Now, Substituting

y = x + y * z

or, y * (1-z) = x

Hence, y = x / ( 1 - z) == FPE

This is an important find. Let's call this as the Final Price Equation or FPE in short.

docs.title: Example of TDS Calculation
docs.text:
Cost Price x = ₹ 2,000 /- TDS z = 10% = 0.1

Hence putting this into FPE

y = x / ( 1 - z) = ₹ 2,000 / ( 1 - 0.1 ) = ₹ 2,222.22/-

Now, we know the final sale price y Let's calculate the T Total tax deducted

T = y * z = ₹ 2,222.22 * 0.1 = ₹ 222.22/-

Hence, TDS becomes ₹ 222.22/- and final sale price is ₹ 2,222.22/-

We know y = x + T Hence x = y - T

Let's put the values:

x = y - T = ₹ 2,222.22 - ₹ 222.22 = ₹ 2,000/-

Hence we get back the the original x even after TDS.

This is wise way to move out the TDS and Tax liabilities towards the paying customer.

docs.title: Example of GST Calculation
docs.text:
Cost Price x = ₹ 2,000 /- GST Slab z = 18% = 0.18

Hence putting this into FPE

y = x / ( 1 - z) = ₹ 2,000 / ( 1 - 0.18 ) = ₹ 2,439.02/-

Now, we know the final sale price y Let's calculate the T Total tax deducted.

T = y * z = ₹ 2,439.02 * 0.1 = ₹ 439.02/-

We know y = x + T Hence x = y - T

Let's put the values:

x = y - T = ₹ 2,439.02 - ₹ 439.02 = ₹ 2,000/-

Hence we get back the the original x even after GST deduction.

This way we can set the correct price of items when selling things.

docs.title: Concept of Antifragility
docs.text:
Antifragility is a property of systems in which they increase in capability to thrive as a result of stressors, shocks, volatility, noise, mistakes, faults, attacks, or failures.

Simply, antifragility is defined as a convex response to a stressors or source of harm (for some range of variation), leading to a positive sensitivity to increase in volatility (or variability, stress, dispersion of outcomes, or uncertainty, what is grouped under the designation "disorder cluster"). Likewise fragility is defined as a concave sensitivity to stressors, leading to a negative sensitivity to increase in volatility. The relation between fragility, convexity, and sensitivity to disorder is mathematical, obtained by theorem, not derived from empirical data mining or some historical narrative. It is a priory.

Rather than eliminate uncertainty and noise, can a system of programming be built that benefits from it? More like human Muscle training.

The Community Cryptography Specification Project (C2SP) is a project that facilitates the maintenance of cryptography specifications using software development methodologies. In other words, C2SP applies the successful processes of open source software development and maintenance to specification documents.

There are several standards that have been developed for various use-cases. The same are listed in the https://github.com/C2SP/C2SP page.

docs.title: age Encryption Standard
docs.text:
https://github.com/C2SP/C2SP/blob/main/age.md

age is a modern file encryption format with multiple pluggable recipients, and seekable streaming encryption.

It uses ChaCha20-Poly1305 with Chunking and payload keys as payload key = HKDF-SHA-256(ikm = file key, salt = nonce, info = "payload")

Very good way to keep the whole thing AHEAD compatible but have streaming. In fact I too had the similar ideas but now this is implemented and usable.

There are 2 variants that are available:

docs.title: FiloSottile / age - Go Implementation for the age Encryption
docs.text:
https://github.com/FiloSottile/age

A simple, modern and secure encryption tool (and Go library) with small explicit keys, no config options, and UNIX-style composability.

Homepage: https://age-encryption.org/ {just a Redirect}

age is a simple, modern and secure file encryption tool, format, and Go library.

Note: This software is designed by Filippo Valsorda who was part of the Go Security Team at Google and Cloudflare DNSSEC & TLS 1.3 Implementation.

Typical flow:

# Generate a Key for Encryption
age-keygen -o key.txt
Output: 
Public key: age1ql3z7hjy54pw3hyww5ayyfg7zqgvc7w3j2elw8zmrj2kg5sfn9aqmcac8p

Note: The Public key is shown but the Private key is stored in the key.txt file. The Private Key is used for decryption. Also the Public key is stored as a comment in the key.txt file for future use.

# Archive and then Encrypt the Data stream
$ tar cvz ~/data | age -r age1ql3z7hjy54pw3hyww5ayyfg7zqgvc7w3j2elw8zmrj2kg5sfn9aqmcac8p > data.tar.gz.age

# Decrypt the Stream
$ age --decrypt -i key.txt data.tar.gz.age > data.tar.gz

Now the file can be restored.

docs.title: magic-wormhole - Get things from one computer to another, safely.
docs.text:
https://github.com/magic-wormhole/magic-wormhole

Get things from one computer to another, safely.

This package provides a library and a command-line tool named wormhole, which makes it possible to get arbitrary-sized files and directories (or short pieces of text) from one computer to another. The two endpoints are identified by using identical "wormhole codes": in general, the sending machine generates and displays the code, which must then be typed into the receiving machine.

The codes are short and human-pronounceable, using a phonetically-distinct wordlist. The receiving side offers tab-completion on the codewords, so usually only a few characters must be typed. Wormhole codes are single-use and do not need to be memorized.

Docs: https://magic-wormhole.readthedocs.io/

The wormhole tool uses PAKE Password-Authenticated Key Exchange, a family of cryptographic algorithms that uses a short low-entropy password to establish a strong high-entropy shared key. This key can then be used to encrypt data. wormhole uses the SPAKE2 algorithm, due to Abdalla and Pointcheval1.

Note: This uses an Internet Relay server to actually bridge the 2 PCs. So internet connection is needed for this to work.

This was presented in PyCon 2016:

Slides http://www.lothar.com/~warner/MagicWormhole-PyCon2016.pdf

Brian Warner - Magic Wormhole- Simple Secure File Transfer - PyCon 2016.mp4

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oFrTqQw0_3c

Here is an example of the Commands:

wormhole send README.md

Output: 

Sending 7924 byte file named 'README.md'
On the other computer, please run: wormhole receive
Wormhole code is: 7-crossover-clockwork

Sending (<-10.0.1.43:58988)..
100%|=========================| 7.92K/7.92K [00:00<00:00, 6.02MB/s]
File sent.. waiting for confirmation
Confirmation received. Transfer complete.

Note: The Wormhole code is the important piece that the other side must know to receive the file.

wormhole receive

Process: 

Enter receive wormhole code: 7-crossover-clockwork
Receiving file (7924 bytes) into: README.md
ok? (y/n): y
Receiving (->tcp:10.0.1.43:58986)..
100%|===========================| 7.92K/7.92K [00:00<00:00, 120KB/s]
Received file written to README.md

Thats it. Its simple and Easy.

docs.title: Command Format for magic-wormhole

To Send a Message:

To Send a File:

To Send a whole directory:

wormhole send [args] DIRNAME

To Receive the message, file or directory:

docs.title: psanford / wormhole-william API Use in Golang
docs.text:
Sending Text:

package main

import (
    "context"
    "fmt"

    "github.com/psanford/wormhole-william/wormhole"
)

func sendText(msg, pass string) error {
    var c wormhole.Client

    ctx := context.Background()

    _, status, err := c.SendText(ctx, msg, wormhole.WithCode(pass))
    if err != nil {
        return fmt.Errorf("failed to initiate send - %v", err)
    }

    // Wait for Transmit to Complete
    s := <-status

    if s.OK {
        return nil
    } else {
        return fmt.Errorf("Send error: %s", s.Error)
    }
}

func main() {
    fmt.Println("Sending Message ....")
    err := sendText("Hari Aum!", "3509-Trfick-Pinggert")
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }
    fmt.Println("Success !")
}

Receive Text:

package main

import (
    "context"
    "fmt"
    "io"

    "github.com/psanford/wormhole-william/wormhole"
)

func receiveText(pass string) (string, error) {
    var c wormhole.Client

    ctx := context.Background()

    msg, err := c.Receive(ctx, pass)
    if err != nil {
        return "", fmt.Errorf("failed to initiate send - %v", err)
    }

    if msg.Type != wormhole.TransferText {
        return "", fmt.Errorf(
            "Expected a text message but got type %s", msg.Type)
    }

    msgBody, err := io.ReadAll(msg)
    if err != nil {
        return "", fmt.Errorf(
            "Failed to read the message body - %v", err)
    }

    return string(msgBody), nil
}

func main() {
    fmt.Println("Receiving Message ....")
    msg, err := receiveText("3509-Trfick-Pinggert")
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }

    fmt.Printf("Got Message: %s\n", msg)
}

docs.title: 🔢 The Formula
docs.text:
Euler’s formula connects complex exponentials to trigonometric functions:

\[ e^{j\theta} = \cos(\theta) + j\sin(\theta) \]

Where: - \( j \) is the imaginary unit (\( j^2 = -1 \)) - \( \theta \) is a real angle in radians

This maps to a point on the unit circle in the complex plane at an angle \( \theta \) from the real axis.

docs.title: 📐 Geometric Meaning
docs.text:
Euler’s formula represents a counterclockwise rotation by angle \( \theta \) on the complex plane:

  • \( e^{j0} = 1 \) (point at 1 on real axis)
  • \( e^{j\frac{\pi}{2}} = j \) (point at top of unit circle)
  • \( e^{j\pi} = -1 \)
  • \( e^{j2\pi} = 1 \) (full circle)

It describes a perfect circle traced out by rotating vector of unit length.

docs.title: 1. Phasors in AC Circuits
docs.text:
Represent sinusoidal signals as rotating vectors:

\[ v(t) = \text{Re}\{ V_0 e^{j(\omega t + \phi)} \} \]

Simplifies addition, differentiation, and impedance calculations.

docs.title: 2. Fourier Transform
docs.text:
Any periodic signal can be expressed as a sum of complex exponentials:

\[ f(t) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} c_n e^{jn\omega t} \]

Forms the foundation of modern signal processing.

docs.title: 3. Modulation in Communications
docs.text: Used to represent carrier and modulated waves for AM/FM and digital communication systems.

docs.title: Firefox Profile using Profilemaker
docs.text:
Home Page: https://ffprofile.com/

Steps:

  1. Download the profile.zip containing everything (You might already have this)
  2. Go to the Firefox Excitable Directory in Windows typically Program Files\Mozilla Firefox and open an Shell. This would ensure that the Firefox exe is in PATH.
  3. Now open the Profile Manager: firefox -no-remote -ProfileManager
  4. Create a new profile in the desired directory.
  5. Let Firefox to open for the first time using the new profile just created.
  6. Type about:support into the URL bar.
  7. Press the open profile folder button. This would open a Explorer window.
  8. Close Firefox window.
  9. Delete everything from the new profile (you will lose all existing data from the profile).
  10. Unzip the profile.zip archive into the folder.
  11. Now the Profile is installed and can be used to open Firefox with the same.
  12. Remember to Update all extensions once the Firefox opens with the new Profile.

docs.title: 📌 Overview
docs.text:
NATS is a high-performance messaging system designed for cloud-native applications, microservices, and distributed systems. It offers core messaging features like pub/sub, request/reply, and queuing with minimal latency and robust scalability.

  • Website: https://nats.io/
  • GitHub: https://github.com/nats-io/nats-server

docs.title: ✅ 1. Install NATS using Docker
docs.text:
# Pull the official NATS server image
$ docker pull nats:latest

# Run NATS server with default configuration
$ docker run -d --name nats-server -p 4222:4222 -p 8222:8222 nats:latest
  • 4222: Main client connection port
  • 8222: HTTP monitoring endpoint

docs.title: ✅ 2. Install NATS CLI (Optional but Useful)
docs.text:
$ curl -L https://github.com/nats-io/natscli/releases/latest/download/nats-$(uname -s)-amd64.tar.gz | tar xz
$ sudo mv nats /usr/local/bin/

# Verify
$ nats --help

docs.title: Option 1: Using Helm
docs.text:
# Add Helm repo
$ helm repo add nats https://nats-io.github.io/k8s/helm/charts/
$ helm repo update

# Install NATS
$ helm install nats nats/nats --namespace nats-io --create-namespace

docs.title: Option 2: Using YAML Manifests
docs.text:
# Clone the repo
$ git clone https://github.com/nats-io/k8s
$ cd k8s/nats-server/

# Apply the manifests
$ kubectl apply -f nats-server.yaml

docs.title: Exposing NATS
docs.text:
• Use NodePort or LoadBalancer for external access.
  • Use kubectl port-forward for local access.

docs.title: 1. Standalone Mode
docs.text: $ docker run -p 4222:4222 nats:latest

docs.title: 2. Cluster Mode
docs.text:
$ docker run -d \
  -p 4222:4222 \
  -p 6222:6222 \
  -p 8222:8222 \
  nats:latest \
  -cluster_name my_cluster \
  -cluster nats://0.0.0.0:6222 \
  -routes nats-route://<another-node>:6222

docs.title: 3. JetStream Mode (for persistence and stream processing)
docs.text:
$ docker run -d -p 4222:4222 -p 8222:8222 \
  nats:latest -js

docs.title: Publish and Subscribe
docs.text:
# Start a subscriber
$ nats sub hello.world

# Start a publisher
$ nats pub hello.world "Hello from NATS!"

docs.title: Request-Reply
docs.text:
# Start a replier
$ nats reply greetings "Hi, how can I help you?"

# Send a request
$ nats request greetings "Hello?"

docs.title: Using JetStream
docs.text:
# Add a stream
$ nats stream add mystream --subjects "foo.*"

# Publish a message
$ nats pub foo.1 "Streamed Message"

# Create a consumer
$ nats consumer add mystream myconsumer

# Read from stream
$ nats consumer next mystream myconsumer

docs.title: SSD Endurance
docs.text:
This is the measure of how long the SSD is going to last. A very key limit on te use of SSDs.

There are two Measures:

  1. TBW = Terabytes Written

    This measures the total amount of data that can be written to the disk before it fails.

    For Example:

    Look at Crucial P3 Plus 500GB PCIe M.2 2280 SSD

    Model No. CT500P3PSSD8

    SSD Endurance (TBW) 110TB

    Means that 110 Terabytes can be written to this SSD before it gets damaged permanently.

  2. DWPD = Disk-Writes Per Day

    This is number of days the SSD would last when the Full capacity of the SSD is written in a Day.

    It's a but convoluted but let us try to understand with an example.

    Let's say an SSD Endurance says 100 DWPD and the SSD has 500GB capacity.

    This means that if 500GB is written every day to the SSD then it would last for 100 days.

    Hence the total SSD Endurance (TBW) = 500GB * 100Days / 1000GB = 50TBW Well that's too less yes, that is true.

sx is the command-line network scanner designed to follow the UNIX philosophy.

The goal of this project is to create the fastest network scanner with clean and simple code.

Repository : https://github.com/v-byte-cpu/sx

It works like repeated ping commands to scan network IP that exist on a give network using ARP.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
go install github.com/v-byte-cpu/sx@latest

This would install in your $GOPATH/bin folder. Make sure that this folder is in your $PATH.

docs.title: Usage Examples
docs.text:
Note

We need to use sudo due to the Network access.

  • Scan the Local network

    sudo sx arp 192.168.1.1/24

  • Scan with JSON Output:

    sudo sx arp --json 192.168.1.1/24

  • Re-scan the Network every 10 Seconds

    sudo sx arp 192.168.0.1/24 --live 10s

docs.title: Tiddly Wiki : Personal Wiki in Single HTML file
Tiddly Wiki : Personal Wiki in Single HTML file
docs.text:
TiddlyWiki: The world's most popular single-file reusable non-linear personal web notebook (est. 2004).

Website: https://tiddlywiki.com/

Sources: https://github.com/TiddlyWiki

Video Tutorial: * Introduction to TiddlyWiki * https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KtCUr83XgyE * Getting Started Video * https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1g66s7UbyuU * TiddlyWiki Tutorial by Francis Meetze * https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLzZCajspPU_UjFn0uy-J9URz0LP4zhxRK * Using TiddlyWiki on Firefox for Android * https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iikkv9orGGI * Experience TiddlyWiki Fluency: Creating a Reading List ADVANCED * https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vsdDs7oOLlg

Download * https://tiddlywiki.com/#GettingStarted * Empty Edition https://tiddlywiki.com/prerelease/#Empty%20Edition * Other Editions https://tiddlywiki.com/prerelease/#Editions

Merits:

  • Nice one but there is a need to switch to a new Markup format.
  • The concept of single file based thing is really nice. We can easily sync or move data. In fact even images or files attached are actually stored inside the same HTML file.
  • We can also attach files from the disk.
  • When this is compared to the Cherry tree this scores well.
  • Being a single file its easy to make portable and share. It can easily be zipped and emailed to other people.
  • Excellent multi-platform capability. Can even work on mobile without any app. However editing on mobile might prove to be a bit difficult.

However there are some downsides.

Demerits: - Upgrades are difficult. - There are artifacts for transport between formats. - If the HTML file is ever corrupted then it would cause damage to all data. It would be very difficult to recover data once the file is corrupt.

docs.title: UPI Payment URI and UPI QR Code
UPI Payment URI and UPI QR Code
How the URI for UPI Looks like
docs.text:
upi://pay?pa=nath23@upi&pn=Aorj&am=100&tn=donate&cu=INR

Here pa=nath23@upi is the UPI ID nath23@upi. The pn=Aorj is the Person / Organization's name whom the ID belongs to. The Amount for transaction is am=100. This can also be a decimal number. Finally the Transaction Type tn=donate for Donation Currency is added at the end cu=INR. When the am part is not there then it becomes a normal UPI ID.

Here is basic QR Code generated using :

https://upiqr.in/

Name   : Pramod Kumar Mahajan
UPI ID : haritech@upi

URI =
upi://pay?cu=INR&pa=haritech@upi&pn=Pramod%20Kumar%20Mahajan

Here is the Basic QR Code.

Now Translating a URI to QR Code using: https://www.qr-code-generator.com/

Using URI:

upi://pay?pa=jaijai@upi&pn=Bhim%20Sen&tn=Vegitables&am=200&cu=INR

Name: Bhim Sen
UPI : jaijai@upi
Transaction : Vegitables
Amount : 200
Currency : INR
